Sept 68 C15 8 1313, Photo by Bea A Corson, Chicago. Purchased at estate sale in 2011 by Victor Grigas Released Public Domain.tiff | caption = Anti-war protestors gather at the ''[[General John Logan Memorial]]'' in [[Grant Park (Chicago)|Grant Park]], [[Chicago]]. | date = August 23–28 | place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] | coordinates = | causes = | goals = | methods = | status = | result = | side1 = Protesters *[[Youth International Party]] *[[National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam]] *[[Women Strike for Peace]] *[[Southern Christian Leadership Conference]] *Other activists | side2 = [[Law enforcement in the United States|Security forces]] *[[Chicago Police Department]] *[[Illinois National Guard]] *[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] | side3 = | leadfigures1 = *[[Abbie Hoffman]] *[[Jerry Rubin]] *[[Rennie Davis]] | leadfigures2 = [[Richard J. Daley]] | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | fatalities = | injuries = 500+ protestors
100+ other civilians
152 police officers (including some with split fingernails) | arrests = | detentions = | charged = | fined = | casualties_label = | notes = | sidebox = }} Protest activity against the Vietnam War took place prior to and during the [[1968 Democratic National Convention]]. In 1967, [[Counterculture of the 1960s|counterculture]] and [[Opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War|anti-Vietnam War]] protest groups had been promising to come to [[Chicago]] and disrupt the convention, and the city promised to maintain law and order. For eight days the protesters were met by the [[Chicago Police Department]] in the streets and parks of Chicago while the [[U.S. Democratic Party]] met at the convention in the [[International Amphitheater]], with the protests climaxing in what a major report later said was a "police riot" on the night of August 28, 1968.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/retropolis/wp/2018/08/24/a-party-that-had-lost-its-mind-in-1968-democrats-held-one-of-historys-most-disastrous-conventions/?utm_term=.1dbe5c1c4fd9|title=‘A party that had lost its mind’: In 1968, Democrats held one of history’s most disastrous conventions|last=|first=|date=August 24, 2018|work=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=}} ==Youth International Party's involvement== {{wikisource|Yippie Workshop Speech}} [[File:Yippie! Button at the Chicago History Museum.jpg|thumb|right|200px|a Yippie! button on display at the [[Chicago History Museum]]]] The [[Youth International Party]] was one of the major groups in the organization of the protests. [[Abbie Hoffman]], [[Jerry Rubin]], and a few friends engaged in conversation at Hoffman's apartment on [[New Year's Eve]], 1967. They discussed the events of the year, such as the [[Summer of Love]] and [[the Pentagon]] demonstration. The idea of having a free music festival in Chicago was suggested to defuse political tension.{{who|date=June 2013}} Over the next week, the Youth International Party (known as Yippie) took shape. Yippie politicized [[hippie]] ideology and used [[Street theatre|street theater]] and other tactics to critique the [[culture of the United States]] and induce change.{{cite book|last=Farber|first=David|title=Chicago '68|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=1988|pages=3–28|isbn=0-226-23801-6}} In preparation for the Chicago convention, the Yippies held the "Yip-In", and the "Yip-Out" at [[Grand Central Terminal|Grand Central Station]] in [[New York City]]. Both events were planned simply as "[[Human Be-In|be-ins]]", with live music. The event was used to promote peace, love and harmony, and as a trial run for Chicago. The black banner of an [[anarchist]] group was hung on the wall, bearing the words, "Up Against the Wall Mother Fucker" in red. Police stood by watching the crowds. As the "Yip-In" progressed, relations between the police and Yippies became strained. Two people climbed a large clock and removed the hands; the police responded by clearing the station. They formed a [[skirmish]] line, ordered the people to disperse, and then started forcing their way through the crowd.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} The "Yip-Out" was similar in purpose, but held in [[Central Park]]. To obtain the permits and aid from New York City officials necessary for the event, Yippies performed a [[sit-in]] at the mayor's office until the Mayor would negotiate on permits. In the end, an agreement was made on staging, electricity, police presence, bathrooms, and other necessities for running a [[List of music festivals|music festival]]. Police milled in the crowd giving considerable leeway to the proceedings which led to a peaceable day.Farber, 38 The Yippies took a radical approach to the Democratic National Convention. They wrote articles, published fliers, made speeches and held rallies and demonstrations, to announce that they were coming to Chicago. Threats were made that nails would be thrown from overpasses to block roads; cars would be used to block intersections, main streets, [[police station]]s and [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]] armories; [[LSD]] would be dumped in the city's [[water supply]] and the convention would be stormed. However, none of these threats came to fruition. Nonetheless, city officials in Chicago prepared for all possible threats.Stien, David Lewis. Living the Revolution; Yippie in Chicago. Indianapolis, Bobbs-Merril Co., 1969 A vilification campaign led by Chicago authorities worked in favor of the Yippies' plan.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} [[File:1968 Democratic National Convention, Chicago. Sept 68 C15 6 1296 , Photo by Bea A Corson, Chicago. Purchased at estate sale in 2011 by Victor Grigas Released Public Domain.tif|thumb|right|270px|[[Chicago Police]] outside the [[Hilton Chicago|Conrad Hilton]] ]] One of the Yippies' main tactics was to use street theatre to create an experience that drew the attention of mainstream America. Yippie activities were used to put across the message that the average American didn't have control over the political process. They tried to show this by purposefully participating in non-traditional activities that would not conceivably affect the decision making process in the convention hall, unlike a "straight" protest with picket lines, marches, and rallies which could conceivably convince delegates of mass support for a program.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} On a Wednesday night, networks moved their coverage away from the Amphitheater where the delegates were voting on the nomination, to a "pitched battle" in front of the [[Hilton Chicago|Conrad Hilton]] hotel.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} ==National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam's involvement== The other main group behind the convention protests was the [[National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam]] (often referred to as "MOBE"). MOBE was an [[umbrella organization]] that included groups who were opposed to American participation in [[Vietnam War|the Vietnam War]]. MOBE was run by a small executive board that set up a general framework for mass demonstrations, sent out invitations to the over 500 groups on its [[mailing list]]s, and coordinated activities between the groups. MOBE recognized and supported all tactics from marching to civil disobedience.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} MOBE's main aim was to get the largest turnouts at its functions. David Dellinger, MOBE chairman, believed that "The tendency to intensify militancy without organizing wide political support [was] self-defeating. But so [was] the tendency to draw way from militancy into milder and more conventional forms of protest."Farber, p. 90 For Chicago, MOBE originally planned for two large-scale marches and an end of convention rally at Soldier Field. The goal was originally a massive show of force outside the International Amphitheatre. MOBE also planned to have workshops and movement centers distributed in 10 parks throughout the city, many in predominantly black areas, to allow demonstrators and participating groups to follow their particular focuses.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} ==Mayor Daley and the City== [[File:19680810 20 Anti-War March.jpg|thumb|270px|This demonstration took place on August 10, 1968 as Chicago was preparing to host the Democratic National Convention.]] In the buildup to the Convention, Chicago mayor [[Richard J. Daley]] repeatedly announced "Law and order will be maintained".{{cite web|url=http://www.stg.brown.edu/projects/1968/reference/timeline.html|title=1968: a timeline of events|publisher=}} Chicago's security forces prepared for the protests during the convention. Besides the standard gun and [[Club (weapon)|billy club]], [[Chicago Police Department]] officers had [[mace (spray)|mace]] and [[riot helmet]]s. For the convention, the CPD borrowed a new portable communications system from the military, thus increasing communication between field officers and command posts. All summer long, [[police officer]]s had received refresher training on [[Riot control|crowd control]] and riot techniques. During the convention itself, Police Academy instructors were with the reserve forces, giving last minute reminders.Farber, 128–32; Walker, 106–20 To satisfy manpower requirements, the City put the force on 12-hour shifts, instead of the normal 8-hour shifts. This gave police commanders approximately 50% more field officers to deal with disturbances. Two-thirds of the officers would continue with the normal police duties with the remaining third available for special assignment. In the Amphitheatre, the City concentrated 500 officers filling various roles. In [[Lincoln Park]], the number of officers patrolling during the daytime was doubled, but the majority of the officers assigned to the Lincoln Park area were held in reserve, ready to respond to any disturbance. In suspected trouble areas, police patrols were heavy. Further away from the center patrols were less frequent. This allowed the police to shift easily and quickly to control a problem without leaving an area unguarded. While maintaining a public image of total enforcement of all city, state, and federal laws, the Narcotics division was quietly reassigned to regular fieldwork, curtailing anti-drug operations during the DNC.Walker, 106–112 [[File:1968 Democratic National Convention, Chicago. Sept 68 C15 1 1295 , Photo by Bea A Corson, Chicago. Purchased at estate sale in 2011 by Victor Grigas Released Public Domain.tif|thumb|right|270px|[[Illinois National Guard]] troops in downtown Chicago]] Police officials and Mayor Daley had worked with the [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]] to create a plan to effectively use the Guard. It would be called up at the beginning of the convention, but held in reserve at strategically placed armories or collection points such as Soldier Field. With the Guard in place at their armories, the CPD could request and receive assistance quickly.Tuttle, 54 ==Permits== Both MOBE and Yippie needed permits from the city in order to hold their respective events. The City had several reasons for denying permits to MOBE and Yippie and thus stalled issuing permits. The City was worried about a black rebellion, independent of the white protesters, during the convention. To avoid trouble, the City used its influence with black community organizations such as The Woodlawn Organization, the Black Consortium, and [[Operation Breadbasket]] to try to keep their constituents calm and peaceful. Some of the militant black leaders were encouraged to leave town during the convention to avoid being implicated in any violence.Walker, Daniel. ''Rights in Conflict''. New York, E. P. Dutton & Co. 1968 The City also believed that having large numbers of white protesters marching through the black ghettos with a heavy police or National Guard escort would inflame the ghettos and set off rioting. Therefore, the City categorically denied any permit that included parks in or march routes through black areas. Another argument the City used to deny permits was that the permits asked the City to set aside local and state ordinances. A city ordinance closed the city parks at 11 pm, although this was not strictly enforced.{{cite book|last1=Gitlin|first1=Todd|title=The Sixties: Years of Hope, Days of Rage|date=1993|publisher=Random House Publishing Group|location=New York|isbn=9780307834027|page=323}} In a letter to Yippie, [[Deputy Mayor]] David Stahl gave eight rules for Yippie to follow, including submitting detailed plans and requirements, following all city, state, and federal ordinances, and toning down the rhetoric.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} The Yippies refused, so the City felt justified in denying Yippie their permits.{{Citation needed|date=March 2010}} In a last-ditch effort, MOBE filed a lawsuit in [[United States district court|federal court]] seeking it to force Chicago to issue permits for a rally in Soldier Field or Grant Park. Judge Lynch, Daley's former law partner, heard the case, and summarily dismissed the request, citing that the city could deny permits on the basis of protecting "public comfort, convenience, and welfare."{{cite book|last1=Cohen|first1=Adam|last2=Taylor|first2=Elizabeth|title=American Pharaoh: Mayor Richard J. Daley|date=2001|publisher=Little, Brown, and Company|isbn=0759524270|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nGem2g467GAC|accessdate=17 July 2016}} ==Convention== {{main|1968 Democratic National Convention}} {{Refimprove section|date=February 2017}} [[File:1968 Democratic National Convention, Chicago. Sept 68 C15 5 1299 , Photo by Bea A Corson, Chicago. Purchased at estate sale in 2011 by Victor Grigas Released Public Domain.tif|thumb|270px|Illinois National guard troops off of [[Michigan Avenue (Chicago)|Michigan Avenue]]]] The start of the convention week's violence is sometimes traced to the shooting of Dean Johnson by Chicago police officers. Dean Johnson, age 17, and another boy were stopped on the sidewalk by the officers for a curfew violation early on the morning of Thursday, August 22. When Johnson drew and fired a pistol at police (the gun misfired), police officers returned fire, hitting Johnson three times.Farber, 165; Walker, 132 The Yippies and SDS hastily organized a [[Funeral|memorial service]] for Johnson, but as one observer noted, due to poor planning "it turned out that no one had made any plans to actually do anything. We just milled around and began to fill up the intersection. Two squad cars pulled up and the cops got out and told us to keep moving ... but they were pretty gentle about it".Stien, David Lewis. ''Living the Revolution; Yippie in Chicago''. Indianapolis, Bobbs-Merril Co., 1969. pp 37–42 On Friday, August 23, the planned protests began. Jerry Rubin and other Yippies attempted to formally nominate the Yippie candidate for president, [[Pigasus (politics)|Pigasus]], a pig. By the time Rubin arrived with Pigasus, several hundred spectators and reporters had gathered on the Civic Center plaza. Police officers were waiting, and as soon as the pig was released, Rubin, folk singer [[Phil Ochs]], and five other Yippies were arrested. [[File:Photography by Victor Albert Grigas (1919-2017) 00235 Chicago Lincoln Park 1968 (37525564422).jpg|thumb|right|200px|People in Lincoln Park during the convention]] [[File:Photography by Victor Albert Grigas (1919-2017) 00234 Lincoln Park Chicago 1968 NBC news (37557030571).jpg|thumb|right|200px|People in Lincoln Park during the convention, being recorded by [[NBC]]]] At 6 a.m. on Saturday, August 24, continuous surveillance began in Lincoln Park. For the previous several nights, the police had cleared Lincoln Park at 11 pm and maintained a significant presence during the day. [[Women Strike for Peace]] attempted to hold a women-only picket at the Hilton Hotel, the main delegate hotel. Despite plans for buses from around the country to bring hundreds of picketers, only 60 or so women showed up. This apparently failed protest was the catalyst for much of the convention week violence as MOBE and the SDS contingent realized that their "'liberal base' [had] finked out big".Farber, 172 It appeared that the expected hundreds of thousands of protesters would not be descending upon Chicago to disrupt the convention with their presence. It was generally agreed upon to not attempt to stay in Lincoln Park after the curfew, but to rather take the protest to the streets.Farber, p. 172 At exactly 11 pm, poet [[Allen Ginsberg]] led protesters out of the park into the streets. SDS leaders organized several hundred protesters to march through the streets chanting things such as 'Peace Now' while the police simply guarded Lincoln Park. When the crowd stopped at Wells and North Avenue, blocking the intersection, a police contingent arrived and cleared the crowd. Eleven people were arrested and several [[police car]]s were stoned before the crowd dispersed into the normal Saturday nightlife.Walker, 138–9 {{double image|right|1968 Democratic National Convention, Chicago. Sept 68 C15 10 1317 , Photo by Bea A Corson, Chicago. Purchased at estate sale in 2011 by Victor Grigas Released Public Domain.tif|200|1968 Democratic National Convention, Chicago. Sept 68 C15 8 1313, Photo by Bea A Corson, Chicago. Purchased at estate sale in 2011 by Victor Grigas Released Public Domain.tiff|200|A speaker with a megaphone (left) addressing a crowd of protestors (right) in [[Grant Park (Chicago)|Grant Park]]}} On Sunday, MOBE had scheduled a 'Meet the Delegates' march and picket. At 2 p.m. there were between 200 and 300 picketers marching across the street from the Conrad Hilton, and another 500 marching south through the Loop chanting, "Hey, Hey LBJ, how many kids did you kill today". After the police arrival, those who were picketing moved into nearby [[Grant Park (Chicago)|Grant Park]] to avoid a mass arrest situation. Once the marchers had reached Grant Park, there was a brief rally where Davis and Hayden claimed the day a success, and then went to Lincoln Park where the Festival of Life music festival was beginning. [[File:August 25, 1968, Hippies in Lincoln Park, Chicago.webm|thumb|right|300px|Anti-war demonstrators in [[Lincoln Park, Chicago]]. The band [[MC5]] can be seen playing]] At 4 pm, the Festival started with [[MC5]], the only band who showed up for the festival. The police did not allow a [[flatbed truck]] to be brought in as a stage, fearing Yippie would use it to incite the crowd. When the [[concession stand]] owner insisted that Yippie stop using his electrical outlets to run the amplification equipment, confusion ensued. While Rubin and other Yippies tried to make frantic deals to get the sound back on, Hoffman used the confusion to try to bring in the flatbed truck. A deal was struck allowing the truck to be parked nearby, but not in, the park. The crowd that had gathered around and on the truck did not realize an agreement had been reached and thought the truck was being sent away. The crowd surged around the truck, pinning in the police officers. Hoffman declared that the police had stopped the music festival, and proceeded to conduct a workshop on dispersal tactics to avoid arrest by police. As the next police shift came on duty, they were informed of the tense situation in the park. Due to the number, frequency, diverseness, and exposure of the threats made by the protesters, the police were concerned about facing protesters armed with unknown weapons and unknown intentions. At 9 pm, police formed a skirmish line around the park bathrooms. This drew a crowd of spectators who heckled the police. The crowd rapidly grew until the police charged into the crowd swinging their batons, scattering the crowd. The protesters exaggerated the violence and numbers of the police, and the police exaggerated the violence and numbers of the protesters. At 11 pm the police pushed the protesters out of the park. Most protesters left the park and congregated nearby, taunting the police. Initially when the police reached the edge of the park, they maintained their skirmish line, however when a squad was ordered to 'clear' Clark Street to keep traffic flowing the police lost control. A running battle began. Yippie Jerry Rubin told a friend "This is fantastic and it's only Sunday night. They might declare [[martial law]] in this town." Order was not restored in [[Old Town, Chicago|Old Town]] until early Monday morning. In Mayor [[Richard J. Daley|Daley]]'s convention report, a list of 152 officers "wounded" on Wednesday's melee was presented. Their wounds ranged from an officer's split fingernail to an officer's [[infra-orbital]] fracture of the left eye.Chicago Department of Law. ''The Strategy of Confrontation; Chicago and the [[Democratic National Convention]], 1968''. Chicago, 1968. pp 65–66 Although the precise number of injured protesters is unknown, Dr. [[Quentin Young]] of the [[Medical Committee for Human Rights]] (MCHR) stated that approximately most of the 500 people treated in the streets suffered from minor injuries and the effects of [[tear gas]]. During the entirety of convention week, 101 civilians were treated for undisclosed injuries, by area hospitals, 45 of those on Wednesday night.Walker, Daniel. ''Rights in Conflict''. New York, [[E. P. Dutton]] & Co. 1968. p 353 On the convention floor, several delegates made statements against Mayor Daley and the CPD, like Senator [[Abraham Ribicoff]] who denounced the use of "Gestapo tactics on the streets of Chicago" in his speech nominating [[George McGovern]]. ''Village Voice'' reporter Paul Cowan asked his editor not to print a story about the throwing of objects at the police, in hope to provoke reprisals to publish a story on the police riot which "seemed to me a far greater evil than the fact that some kids had wanted to provoke it".Gitlin, 330 The rest of the convention week violence followed the pattern set Sunday night. Protestors were joined on 28 August by the [[Poor People's Campaign]], now led by the [[Southern Christian Leadership Conference]]'s [[Ralph Abernathy]]. This group had a permit and was split off from other demonstrators before being allowed to proceed to the amphitheater. The hard line taken by the City was also seen on the convention floor itself.{{cite web|last=Blobaum|first=Dean|title=A Chronology|url=http://chicago68.com/c68chron.html|work=Chicago '68|accessdate=3 October 2012|date=16 October 2011}} In 1968, [[Terry Southern]] described the convention hall as "exactly like approaching a [[military installation]]; barbed-wire, checkpoints, the whole bit".{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/convention96/retro/southern.html |title=Terry Southern reports from the 1968 Democratic Convention - November 1968 |author= |date= |website=pbs.org/newshour |publisher=[[Online NewsHour]] |access-date= |quote=}} Inside the convention, journalists such as [[Mike Wallace]] and [[Dan Rather]] were roughed up by security; both these events were broadcast live on television. Subsequently, the ''Walker Report'' to the [[U.S. National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence|National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence]] assigned blame for the mayhem in the streets to the police force, calling the violence a "[[police riot#United States|police riot]]". It later became said that on that night, America voted for Richard M. Nixon.{{cite news|url=https://select.nytimes.com/mem/archive/pdf?res=FA0612FB3A541B7B93C0A91789D95F4C8685F9|title=U.S. Study scores Chicago violence as "a police riot"|author=Max Frankel|publisher=''The New York Times''|page=1|date=1968-12-02|accessdate=2007-12-31}} ==See also== *"[[The whole world is watching]]" *''[[Medium Cool]]'' - a fictional movie using real footage of the Chicago Convention demonstrations as backdrop * [[Protests of 1968]] * [[List of incidents of civil unrest in the United States]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * ''[[Miami and the Siege of Chicago]]: An Informal History of the Republican and Democratic Conventions of 1968''. [[Norman Mailer]], New York: New American Library, 1968. ==External links== *[http://www.press.uchicago.edu/Misc/Chicago/238012.html An excerpt] from ''Chicago '68'' by David Farber. *[http://www.press.uchicago.edu/Misc/Chicago/740782.html An excerpt] from ''No One Was Killed: The Democratic National Convention, August 1968'' by [[John Schultz (writer)|John Schultz]]. *[http://www.press.uchicago.edu/Misc/Chicago/465036.html An excerpt] from ''Battleground Chicago: The Police and the 1968 Democratic National Convention'' by [[Frank Kusch]]. *[http://artandsocialissues.cmaohio.org/web-content/pages/war_perlin.html Art and Social Issues] Offers a description of Bernard Perlin's ''Mayor Daley'' which depicts protests during the 1968 Democratic National Convention. {{Commons category|1968 Democratic National Convention}} {{Chicago Seven|state=expanded}} {{Anti-Vietnam}} {{Illinois riots}} {{1968 protests}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Democratic National Convention Protest Activity}} [[Category:1968 Democratic National Convention]] [[Category:1968 in Illinois]] [[Category:1968 protests]] [[Category:1968 riots|Democratic National Conventions]] [[Category:Chicago Police Department]] [[Category:Counterculture of the 1960s]] [[Category:Democratic Party (United States) presidential campaigns, 1968]] [[Category:Political riots]] [[Category:Political violence in the United States]] [[Category:Protest marches in Chicago]] [[Category:Protests against the Vietnam War]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in Chicago]] [[Category:United States presidential election, 1968]] [[Category:20th century in Chicago]] [[Category:August 1968 events]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]]

{{Infobox civilian attack | title = 1984 New York City Subway shooting | image = | caption = | location = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States|U.S.]] | coordinates = | date = December 22, 1984 | time = | timezone = | type = [[Self-defense]] | fatalities = | injuries = 4 | victims = Barry Allen, Troy Canty, Darrell Cabey, James Ramseur | weapons = [[Smith & Wesson Model 38]] }} The '''1984 New York City Subway shooting''' took place on December 22, 1984, when four teenagers, {{ndash}} Barry Allen, Troy Canty, Darrell Cabey and James Ramseur {{ndash}} were shot by Bernhard Goetz on a [[New York City Subway]] train in [[Manhattan]].<ref name="johnson1987">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/20/nyregion/youth-shot-in-subway-says-he-didn-t-approach-goetz.html |title=Youth Shot In Subway Says He Didn't Approach Goetz |newspaper=The New York Times |date=May 20, 1987 |last=Johnson |first=Kirk |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160810024304/http://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/20/nyregion/youth-shot-in-subway-says-he-didn-t-approach-goetz.html |archivedate=August 10, 2016 |df= }}</ref><ref name="NYT_1987-05-02" /><ref name="Brooks">{{JSTOR|25112354}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated162">{{cite book |title=Political Trials in History: From Antiquity to the Present |editor=Ronald Christenson |date=January 1991 |isbn=0-88738-406-4 |publisher=Transaction Publishers |pages=162–163}}</ref> All four were seriously wounded.
Goetz, who had used an unlicensed firearm in the shooting, surrendered to police nine days later and was charged with [[attempted murder]], [[assault]], [[endangerment|reckless endangerment]], and several firearms offenses. A jury found him not guilty of all charges except for one count of carrying an unlicensed firearm, for which he served eight months of a one-year sentence. In 1996, Cabey, who had been left [[paraplegic]] and brain damaged as a result of his injuries, obtained a civil judgment of $43 million against Goetz.<ref name="kelley2000">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/09/10/nyregion/following-up-still-seeking-payment-from-bernard-goetz.html?ref=darrellcabey |work=The New York Times |first=Tina |last=Kelley |title=FOLLOWING UP; Still Seeking Payment From Bernard Goetz |date=September 10, 2000 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170819105229/http://www.nytimes.com/2000/09/10/nyregion/following-up-still-seeking-payment-from-bernard-goetz.html?ref=darrellcabey |archivedate=August 19, 2017 |df= }}</ref>
The incident sparked a nationwide debate on [[Race and crime in the United States|race and crime]] in major cities, the legal limits of [[self-defense]], and the extent to which the citizenry could rely on the police to secure their safety.<ref name="Brooks" /> Goetz, dubbed the "Subway Vigilante" by the New York press, came to symbolize New Yorkers' frustrations with the high [[Crime in New York City|crime rates of the 1980s]]. He was both praised and vilified in the media and public opinion. The incident has also been cited as a contributing factor to the groundswell movement against urban crime and disorder,<ref name="autogenerated1985">{{cite web|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,956277,00.html|title=Behavior: Low Profile for a Legend Bernard Goetz|first=John|last=Leo|date=21 January 1985|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2017|via=www.time.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822234059/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,956277,00.html|archivedate=22 August 2013|df=}}</ref> and the successful [[National Rifle Association]] campaigns to loosen restrictions on the [[concealed carry]]ing of firearms.<ref name="huffingtonpost1">{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/richard-feldman/bernie-goetz-the-subway-g_b_6369128.html |work=The Huffington Post |title=Bernie Goetz 'The Subway Gunman' 30 Years Later |date=December 22, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150711131011/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/richard-feldman/bernie-goetz-the-subway-g_b_6369128.html |archivedate=July 11, 2015 |df= }}</ref>
==Context and background== {{Main|New York City Subway#Crime|l1=New York City Subway crime|Crime in New York City}} Bernhard Goetz stated that, while transporting electronic equipment in 1981, he was attacked in the [[Canal Street (IRT Lexington Avenue Line)|Canal Street]] subway station by three youths in an attempted [[robbery]].<ref name="NYT_1985-01-01">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/01/nyregion/man-tells-police-he-shot-youths-in-subway-train.html |title=Man Tells Police He Shot Youths In Subway Train |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 1, 1985 |last=Daley |first=Suzanne |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170902233449/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/01/nyregion/man-tells-police-he-shot-youths-in-subway-train.html |archivedate=September 2, 2017 |df= }}</ref> The attackers smashed Goetz into a plate-glass door and threw him to the ground, permanently injuring his chest and knee.<ref name="Friedman"/> Goetz assisted an off-duty officer in arresting one of them; the other two attackers escaped. Goetz was angered when the arrested attacker spent less than half the time in the police station spent by Goetz himself, and he was angered further when this attacker was charged only with [[criminal mischief]] for ripping Goetz's jacket.<ref name="Time_1985-04-08"/><ref name="Friedman"/> Goetz subsequently applied for a [[Concealed carry in the United States|permit to carry a concealed handgun]], on the basis of routinely carrying valuable equipment and large sums of cash, but his application was denied for insufficient need.<ref name="Time_1985-04-08"/> He bought a 5-shot [[.38 Special|.38-caliber]] revolver during a trip to [[Florida]].<ref name="Time_1985-04-08"/>
==Incident== [[File:2 Train on the 96th Street Platform.jpg|thumb|right|The shooting occurred on the [[2 (New York City Subway service)|2]] service (pictured).]] [[File:Shooting Car in service on 4.jpg|thumb|right|Car 7657, on which the shooting occurred, in operation on the [[4 (New York City Subway service)|4]] service.]] In the early afternoon of Saturday, December 22, 1984, four [[African-American]] men from [[the Bronx]]—Barry Allen, Troy Canty, and Darrell Cabey, all 19; and James Ramseur, 18—boarded a downtown {{NYCS|2}} train ([[IRT Broadway–Seventh Avenue Line|Broadway–Seventh Avenue express]]). The men, each of whom previously had been arrested and convicted at least once, were on their way to rob a [[video arcade]] in Manhattan.<ref name="NYT_1987-05-02" /><ref name="NYT_1985-01-10">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/10/nyregion/4-youths-shot-by-goetz-faced-criminal-counts.html |title=4 Youths Shot By Goetz Faced Criminal Counts |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 10, 1985 |last=Raab |first=Selwyn |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170819104808/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/10/nyregion/4-youths-shot-by-goetz-faced-criminal-counts.html |archivedate=August 19, 2017 |df= }}</ref> When the train arrived at the [[14th Street (IRT Broadway – Seventh Avenue Line)|14th Street]] station in Manhattan, fifteen to twenty other passengers remained with them in [[R22 (New York City Subway car)|R22 subway car 7657]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nycsubway.org/perl/show?72501 |title=Showing Image 72501 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306042055/http://www.nycsubway.org/perl/show?72501 |archivedate=2009-03-06 |df= }}</ref><ref name="carinterior" /> the seventh car of the ten-car train.<ref name="Lesly">{{cite book |title=Subway Gunman: A Juror's Account of the Bernhard Goetz Trial |author=Lesly, Mark |publisher=British American Publishing |year=1988 |isbn=0-945167-08-3 |authorlink=Mark Lesly}}</ref><!--page23--><ref name="Fletcher">{{cite book |title=A Crime of Self-Defense: Bernhard Goetz and the Law on Trial |last=Fletcher |first=George P. |publisher=University of Chicago Press |date=June 1990 |isbn=0-226-25334-1}}</ref>
At the 14th Street station, Goetz entered the car through the rearmost door, crossed the aisle and took a seat on the long bench across from the door. Canty was across the aisle from him, lying on the long bench just to the right of the door. Allen was seated to Canty's left, on the short seat on the other side of the door. Ramseur and Cabey were seated across from the door and to Goetz's right, on the short seat by the conductor's cab.<ref name="Lesly" /> According to Goetz's statement to the police, approximately ten seconds later, Canty asked him, "How are you doing?" Goetz responded, "Fine." According to Goetz, the four men gave signals to each other, and shortly thereafter Canty and Allen rose from their seats and moved over to the left of Goetz, blocking him off from the other passengers in the car. By Goetz's account, Canty then said, "Give me five dollars." Canty and Ramseur testified at the criminal trial that they were [[begging|panhandling]], and had only requested the money, not demanded it. Cabey did not testify and Allen took the [[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fifth Amendment]].
===Sequence of shots=== Sources differ in reporting the sequence of shots fired, and whether Cabey was shot once or twice. The following are four versions from significant or reliable sources describing the sequence of shots:
====Cabey shot on the fourth and fifth shots==== Prior to the criminal trial, the media reported that Cabey had been shot on the fourth shot and then again on the fifth shot, with Goetz saying, "You don't look too bad, here's another," or, "You seem all right, here's another."<ref name="NYT_1985-02-28" /> This sequence of shots was discredited at the criminal trial when it was revealed that Cabey was shot once in the left side; however, some media still reported<ref name="NYT_1996-04-24" /> this sequence long after the criminal trial.
====Cabey shot on the fifth shot==== "Speed is everything," Goetz said in a videotaped statement made after he surrendered nine days later.<ref name="Lesly" /><!--60--> He told police that while still seated, he planned a "pattern of fire" from left to right. He then stood, stepped clear of Canty, drew his revolver, turned back to Canty, and fired four shots, one at each man, then fired a fifth shot.<ref name="Lesly" /><!--60,153--> At the civil trial years later he said, "I was trying to get as many of them as I could."<ref name="NEWS_1996-04-13">{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/1996/04/13/1996-04-13_cool_goetz_tells_story_he_go.html |title=Cool Goetz Tells Story He Got As Many As He Could Shoot |newspaper=Daily News |date=April 13, 1996 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100122074528/http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/1996/04/13/1996-04-13_cool_goetz_tells_story_he_go.html |archivedate=January 22, 2010}}</ref> Other sources repeated Goetz's statements to New York City police as to the sequence of shots: Canty was shot first, then Allen, then Ramseur, then Cabey.<ref name="Fletcher" /><!--117--><ref name="Lesly" /><!--251--> In the related proceeding ''[[People v. Goetz]]'',<!-- discussed below at [[Bernhard_Goetz#First_and_second_grand_juries|First and second grand juries]],--> the [[New York Court of Appeals]] summarized the incident:
{{Quote|It appears from the evidence before the Grand Jury that Canty approached Goetz, possibly with Allen beside him, and stated "Give me five dollars." Neither Canty nor any of the other youths displayed a weapon. Goetz responded by standing up, pulling out his handgun, and firing four shots in rapid succession. The first shot hit Canty in the chest; the second struck Allen in the back; the third went through Ramseur's arm and into his left side; the fourth was fired at Cabey, who apparently was then standing in the corner of the car, but missed, deflecting instead off of a wall of the conductor's cab. After Goetz briefly surveyed the train scene around him, he fired another shot at Cabey, who then was sitting on the end bench of the car. The bullet entered the rear of Cabey's side and severed his spinal cord.<ref name="68_NY2d_96"/>}}
According to his statements to police, Goetz checked the first two men to make sure that they had been "taken care of," then upon seeing that the fourth man, Cabey, was now sitting down and seemed unhurt, said, "You seem to be all right, here's another," and fired at him again.<ref name="NYT_1987-04-30" /> Cabey was shot only once,<ref name="Lesly" /><ref name="NYT_1996-04-24" /><ref name="NYT_1996-04-26">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/26/opinion/c-correction-003743.html |title=Correction |newspaper=The New York Times |date=April 26, 1996 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306190354/http://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/26/opinion/c-correction-003743.html |archivedate=March 6, 2016 |df= }}</ref><!--24--><ref name="Fletcher" /><!--175--><ref name="NYT_1987-05-12" /> a fact not made known to Goetz or his attorneys until shortly before the trial. One bullet missed, fragmenting on the steel cab wall behind Cabey. (The missed shot would also be the basis of a charge of [[endangerment|reckless endangerment]] of other passengers.)<ref name="NYT_1987-05-12">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/nyregion/judge-refuses-immunity-to-youth-shot-by-goetz.html |title=Judge Refuses Immunity To Youth Shot By Goetz |newspaper=The New York Times |date=May 12, 1987 |last=Johnson |first=Kirk |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171110083322/http://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/nyregion/judge-refuses-immunity-to-youth-shot-by-goetz.html |archivedate=November 10, 2017 |df= }}</ref>
====Cabey shot on the fourth shot==== At the Bronx civil trial, Goetz testified the first shot was Canty, Allen second, the third shot missed, Cabey fourth, and Ramseur fifth. The following similar shooting sequence is from Goetz's website:
{{Quote|I decided to shoot as many as I could as quickly as I could. I did a fast draw, and shot with one hand (my right), pulling the trigger prior to the gun being aligned on the targets. All actual shots plus my draw time occurred easily within 1.6 seconds or less. This is not as difficult to do as some might think, and occasionally I give a description of the technique along with a re-enactment. The first shot hit Canty in the center of the chest. After the first shot my vision changed and I lost my sense of hearing. The second shot hit lightning fast Barry Allen in the upper rear shoulder as he was ducking (later the bullet was removed from his arm). The third shot hit the subway wall just in front of Cabey; the fourth shot hit Cabey in the left side (severing his spinal cord and rendering him paraplegic). The fifth shot hit Ramseur's arm on the way into his left side. I immediately looked at the first two to make sure they were "taken care of," and then attempted to shoot Cabey again in the stomach, but the gun was empty. I thought Cabey was shot twice after reading a media account no shots missed; I had lost count of the shots and while under adrenaline I didn't even hear the shots or feel the kick of the gun. 'You don't look too bad, here's another', is a phrase I came up with later when trying to explain the shooting while I was under the impression that Cabey was shot twice. Cabey, who was briefly standing prior to the shooting, was sitting on the subway bench during all attempted shots. The others were standing. Shortly after the shooting my vision and hearing returned to normal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.berniegoetz.net |title=Bernie Goetz for Public Advocate |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051105014810/http://berniegoetz.net/ |archivedate=2005-11-05 |df= }}</ref>}}
Goetz does a shooting demonstration (five shots in 1.0 seconds) on the [[Biography Channel]] show ''[[Aftermath with William Shatner]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1656896/episodes?season=1&ref_=tt_eps_sn_1 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-10-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180514223547/https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1656896/episodes?season=1&ref_=tt_eps_sn_1 |archivedate=2018-05-14 |df= }} Bernhard Goetz/Aftermath with William Shatner</ref>
====''Time'' magazine's theory (April 8, 1985)==== Goetz said one of the "boys" made gestures that may have implied he had a weapon.<ref name="Time_1985-04-08"/> Goetz rose and partly unzipped his jacket where the revolver was concealed, and plotted his "pattern of fire" for shooting them.<ref name="Time_1985-04-08"/> He asked Canty what he had said, and he repeated his statement. At this, Goetz unzipped his jacket the rest of the way, drew the gun, assumed a combat stance gripping the revolver with both hands, and shot Canty through the center of his body. He then turned to shoot Allen who had tried to flee, hitting him in the back, and then shot Ramseur, wounding him in the chest and arm.<ref name="Time_1985-04-08"/> He then shot again, at Cabey, but may have missed. According to Goetz he then approached Cabey and shot him on the ground; however, another witness disputed that Goetz shot Cabey a second time.<ref name="Time_1985-04-08"/>
===Cabey and the "here's another" issue=== Cabey ended up slumped in the short seat in the corner of the car next to the conductor's cab.<ref name="carinterior">[http://www.nycsubway.org/perl/show?3217 Photo – interior of similar model car, an R-17] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090213191435/http://www.nycsubway.org/perl/show?3217 |date=2009-02-13 }}, [[New York Transit Museum]] – Goetz car was an R-22 with fiberglass seating</ref> Whether Cabey was struck by the fourth shot or by the fifth was critical to Goetz's claim of self-defense; this issue was fiercely contested at trial.<ref name="Fletcher" /><!--69,126--> Medical testimony said that such an injury would render the lower half of Cabey's body instantly useless. According to the prosecution, the fourth shot missed; then Goetz shot a seated Cabey at point-blank range with the fifth. The defense theory of how Cabey ended up in the seat was that he was standing when hit by the fourth shot, then collapsed into the seat due to the lurching and swaying of the train; with the fifth shot being the shot that missed.<ref name="Lesly" /><!--208-->
A summary of Goetz's statements to the police had become public two months after the incident, drawing intense media coverage. Probably most damaging to Goetz's public support and to his claim of acting in self-defense was his statement that he had said, "You don't look so bad, here's another," before firing at Cabey a second time. Media concentration on the summary's more damning portions created a public mindset that a wounded Cabey was shot a second time, with the second shot taken in a premeditated and deliberate way—an impression that stood uncorrected until the criminal trial two years later.<ref name="NYT_1985-02-28" /> The notion that Cabey was shot twice would still occasionally appear in mainstream sources over a decade later, as it did in a 1996 ''New York Times'' editorial.<ref name="NYT_1996-04-26" />
At trial, one witness testified that Goetz approached to within "two to three feet" of a seated Cabey, then demonstrated how Goetz stood directly in front of Cabey and fired downward, a description that matched Goetz's published statements.<ref name="Lesly" />{{rp|138}}<ref name="Fletcher" />{{rp|123–125}} Eight other independent witnesses testified that all shots came in "rapid succession";<ref name="Fletcher" />{{rp|171}} one of these said the firing lasted "about a second".<ref name="Lesly" />{{rp|102}} None of the eight heard a pause before the final shot, and none saw Goetz standing in front of Cabey.<ref name="Lesly" />{{rp|235}}
Whether Goetz actually said aloud the words "You don't look so bad, here's another" or only thought them is still a matter of dispute. He has subsequently denied on several occasions making the statement.<ref>Severin Mevissen: [http://www.stern.de/lifestyle/leute/:Was-...-...-Bernhard-Goetz/609378.html Was macht eigentlich ... Bernhard Goetz?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081109162152/http://www.stern.de/lifestyle/leute/:Was-...-...-Bernhard-Goetz/609378.html |date=2008-11-09 }}'' [[Stern (magazine)|Stern]] 5/2008, p. 154.</ref> One source said, "In all probability, the defendant uttered these words only to himself and probably not even mouthing the words, but just saying them in his own mind as he squeezed the trigger that fifth time."<ref name="Fletcher" />{{rp|175}}
===Flight and surrender=== The terrified passengers ran to the other end and out of the car, leaving behind the two women who had been closest to the shooting, fallen or knocked down by the exodus, and immobilized by fear. Goetz talked to them to make sure they were not injured, then was approached by the [[Conductor (transportation)|conductor]] of the train. Goetz stated, "They tried to rob me."<ref name="Lesly" />{{rp|102}} The conductor asked whether Goetz was a police officer, receiving the reply, "No." Some time after a brief conversation in which he refused to hand over his revolver,<ref name="Lesly" />{{rp|102}} Goetz jumped to the tracks and ran south through the tunnel to the Chambers Street station, where he exited the system.<ref name="Fletcher"/> He went home to gather some belongings, then rented a car and drove north to [[Bennington, Vermont]], where he burned his blue jacket and dismantled the revolver, scattering the pieces in the woods north of town. He drove around New England for several days, registering at motels under various names and paying in cash.
On December 26, an anonymous hotline caller told New York City police that Goetz matched the gunman's description, owned a gun, and had been mugged previously.<ref name="NYT_1985-01-02">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/02/nyregion/irt-suspect-is-charged-as-fugitive.html |title=IRT Suspect Is Charged As Fugitive |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 2, 1985 |last=Daley |first=Suzanne |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202070515/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/02/nyregion/irt-suspect-is-charged-as-fugitive.html |archivedate=February 2, 2017 |df= }}</ref><ref name="NYT_1985-01-04_2">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/04/news/goetz-drove-across-new-england-for-several-days-before-surrender.html |title=Goetz Drove Across New England For Several Days Before Surrender |newspaper=The New York Times |last=Daley |first=Suzanne |date=January 4, 1985 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202070728/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/04/news/goetz-drove-across-new-england-for-several-days-before-surrender.html |archivedate=February 2, 2017 |df= }}</ref> On December 29, Goetz called his neighbor, Myra Friedman, who told him that police had come by his apartment looking for him, and had left notes asking to be contacted as soon as possible.<ref name="Friedman"/> He gave his side of the story to Friedman, and described his psychological state at the time:<ref name="Friedman">{{cite news |first=Myra |last=Friedman |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VMEBAAAAMBAJ&printsec=frontcover&cad=0_0#PPA34,M1 |title=My Neighbor Bernie Goetz |publisher=''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' |date=February 18, 1985}}</ref>
{{quote|Myra, in a situation like this, your mind, you're in a combat situation. Your mind is functioning. You're not thinking in a normal way. Your memory isn't even working normally. You are so hyped up. Your vision actually changes. Your field of view changes. Your capabilities change. What you are capable of changes. You are under adrenaline, a drug called adrenaline. And you respond very quickly, and you think very quickly. That's all. [...] You think! You think, you analyze, and you act. And in any situation, you just have to think more quickly than your opposition. That's all. You know. Speed is very important.}}
Goetz returned to New York City on December 30, turned in the car, picked up some clothing and business papers at his apartment, rented another car and drove back to New England. Shortly after noon the next day, he walked into the [[Concord, New Hampshire]], police headquarters and told the officer on duty, "I am the person they are seeking in New York."<ref name="NYT_1985-01-04_2" />
===Statements to police=== Once the officer realized that Goetz was a genuine suspect, Goetz was given a [[Miranda warning]] and he waived his right to have an attorney present. After an interview that lasted over an hour, a Concord detective asked Goetz to consent to making an [[Sound recording and reproduction|audiotaped]] statement. Goetz agreed, and a two-hour statement was recorded. That evening, New York City detectives and an [[district attorney|assistant district attorney]] arrived in Concord, and Goetz submitted to a two-hour [[videotape]]d interview. Both interviews were eventually played back for the grand juries, the criminal trial, and a civil trial years later. When the audiotape was first played in open court, Goetz was described by ''[[The New York Times]]'' as "confused and emotional, alternately horrified by and defensive about his actions, and obsessed with justifying them."<ref name="NYT_1987-05-03">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/03/weekinreview/everybody-is-edgy-as-goetz-trial-opens.html?pagewanted=all |title=Everybody Is Edgy As Goetz Trial Opens |newspaper=The New York Times |date=May 3, 1987 |last=Johnson |first=Kirk |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306204855/http://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/03/weekinreview/everybody-is-edgy-as-goetz-trial-opens.html?pagewanted=all |archivedate=March 6, 2016 |df= }}</ref>
In his statements, Goetz described his past [[robbery|mugging]], in which he was injured and the only assailant arrested went unpunished. He called New York City "lawless" and expressed contempt for its justice system, calling it a "joke," a "sham," and "a disgrace". Goetz said that when the four men he shot surrounded him on the train, he feared being "beaten to a pulp" as well as being robbed.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bookrags.com/highbeam/goetz-labels-himself-victim-and-hb/ |title=Goetz Labels Himself Victim And 'Murderer' |newspaper=Boston Globe |date=May 14, 1987 |last=Kennedy |first=John H. |accessdate=2016-08-01 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605043429/http://www.bookrags.com/highbeam/goetz-labels-himself-victim-and-hb/ |archivedate=June 5, 2011 |df= }}</ref> He denied any premeditation for the shooting, something that had been speculated on by the press.<ref name="Lesly" />{{rp|58}} Asked what his intentions were when he drew his revolver, Goetz replied, "My intention was to murder them, to hurt them, to make them suffer as much as possible."<ref name="NYT_1987-04-30">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/30/nyregion/you-have-to-think-in-a-cold-blooded-way.html?pagewanted=all |title=... You Have To Think In A Cold-Blooded Way |newspaper=The New York Times |date=April 30, 1987 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170607233032/http://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/30/nyregion/you-have-to-think-in-a-cold-blooded-way.html?pagewanted=all |archivedate=June 7, 2017 |df= }}</ref> Later in the tape, Goetz said, "If I had more bullets, I would have shot 'em all again and again. My problem was I ran out of bullets." He added, "I was gonna, I was gonna gouge one of the guys' [Canty's] eyes out with my keys afterwards", but said he stopped when he saw the fear in his eyes.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1322122.html<!-- |url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/73818658.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=May+14%2C+1987&author=Margot+Hornblower&desc=Intended+to+Gouge+Eye+Of+Teen%2C+Goetz+Tape+Says%3B%60My+Problem+Was+I+Ran+Out+of+Bullets%27 --> |title=Intended to Gouge Eye Of Teen, Goetz Tape Says; 'My Problem Was I Ran Out of Bullets' |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=May 14, 1987 |last=Hornblower |first=Margot |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023052130/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1322122.html |archivedate=October 23, 2012 |df= }}</ref> At the criminal trial, Goetz's defense attorneys, [[Barry Slotnick]] and [[Mark M. Baker]], argued that this and other extreme statements by Goetz were the product of emotion and an overactive imagination.
Goetz was brought back to Manhattan on January 3, 1985 and [[Arraignment|arraigned]] on four charges of attempted murder, with bail set at $50,000. He was held in [[protective custody]] at the [[Rikers Island]] prison hospital.<ref name="NYT_1985-01-04">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/04/nyregion/no-headline-193196.html |title=No Headline |quote=Under tight security, Bernhard Hugo Goetz was returned ... |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 4, 1985 |last=Chambers |first=Marcia |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171128135252/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/04/nyregion/no-headline-193196.html |archivedate=November 28, 2017 |df= }}</ref> Refusing offers of bail assistance from the public and from his family, he posted bail with his own funds and was released on bond January 8.<ref name="NYT_1985-01-09">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/09/nyregion/goetz-posts-bail-and-is-freed-youths-he-shot-won-t-testify.html |title=Goetz Posts Bail And Is Freed; Youths He Shot Won't Testify |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 9, 1985 |last=Chambers |first=Marcia |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171128104113/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/09/nyregion/goetz-posts-bail-and-is-freed-youths-he-shot-won-t-testify.html |archivedate=November 28, 2017 |df= }}</ref>
===Early reports=== Because of the loudness of the shots inside the confined space of the subway car, there were initial witness reports that suggested the gun involved was a [[.357 Magnum]] revolver. Goetz alluded to these reports in a December 2004 interview on the ''[[Opie and Anthony]]'' radio show, saying that the first shot he fired that afternoon had been unusually loud in part because it was the first shot fired by the small-frame [[.38 Special|.38 caliber]] revolver after the factory tests, which "cleaned the barrel."
After the incident, rumors spread that Goetz had been threatened with sharpened screwdrivers.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/anniversary/35th/n_8601/ |title=The Joy of Goetz |journal=New York |last=Crouch |first=Stanley |date=April 7, 2003 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080902011058/http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/anniversary/35th/n_8601/ |archivedate=September 2, 2008 |df= }}</ref> This rumor was published as fact by some newspapers including ''The New York Times'';<ref name="NYT_1987-05-02"/><ref name="NYT_1984-12-30">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/30/weekinreview/the-little-known-world-of-the-vigilante.html |title=The Little-Known World Of The Vigilante |newspaper=The New York Times |date=December 30, 1984 |last=Sanger |first=David E. |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206133823/http://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/30/weekinreview/the-little-known-world-of-the-vigilante.html |archivedate=February 6, 2017 |df= }}</ref> however, neither Goetz nor the men made any such claim. During his subsequent statement to the police, Goetz expressed a belief that none of the young men had been armed.<ref name="NYT_1987-05-22">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/22/nyregion/the-goetz-defense-overcome-taped-statement-and-eyewitness-testimony.html?pagewanted=all |title=The Goetz Defense: Overcome Taped Statement And Eyewitness Testimony |date=May 22, 1987 |last=Shipp |first=E. R. |newspaper=The New York Times |authorlink=E. R. Shipp |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306112544/http://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/22/nyregion/the-goetz-defense-overcome-taped-statement-and-eyewitness-testimony.html?pagewanted=all |archivedate=March 6, 2016 |df= }}</ref> Paramedics and police did find a total of three screwdrivers on two of the men; when Canty testified at Goetz's criminal trial, he said they were to be used to break into video arcade change boxes and not as weapons.<ref name="NYT_1987-05-02">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/02/nyregion/goetz-shooting-victim-says-youths-weren-t-threatening.html |title=Goetz Shooting Victim Says Youths Weren't Threatening |newspaper=The New York Times |date=May 2, 1987 |last=Johnson |first=Kirk |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171104043628/http://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/02/nyregion/goetz-shooting-victim-says-youths-weren-t-threatening.html |archivedate=November 4, 2017 |df= }}</ref>
==Shooter== {{about||the Norwegian judge|Bernhard Getz|the German actor|Bernhard Goetzke|section=yes}} {{Infobox person | name = Bernhard Goetz | image = <!--Bernhard Goetz.jpg--> | image_upright = | caption = Goetz in 2013 | birth_name = Bernard Hugo Goetz<ref>{{cite web |url=http://search.ancestry.com/search/category.aspx?cat=123&o_xid=21837&o_lid=21837 |title=Birth Records - Baptism & Christening at Ancestry.com |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101231042259/http://search.ancestry.com/search/category.aspx?cat=123&o_xid=21837&o_lid=21837 |archivedate=2010-12-31 |df= }}</ref> | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1947|11|7|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Queens]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | nationality = American | religion = }}
Bernhard Goetz was born on November 7, 1947, in [[Kew Gardens, Queens]], New York City, the son of Gertrude (Karlsberg) and Bernhard Willard Goetz, Sr. His parents were [[German American|German-born]] immigrants who had met in the United States;<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1986-12-14/features/8604030432_1_mugged-subway-vigilante-new-york-city-subway/2 |work=Chicago Tribune |title=Wolf Or Wimp? |date=December 14, 1986 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20120329094850/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1986-12-14/features/8604030432_1_mugged-subway-vigilante-new-york-city-subway/2 |archivedate=March 29, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rvhNqhrgkLcC&pg=PA47&lpg=PA47|title=Quiet Rage: Bernie Goetz in a Time of Madness|first=Lillian B.|last=Rubin|date=14 August 1988|publisher=University of California Press|via=Google Books}}</ref> Goetz's father was [[Lutheranism|Lutheran]]; his mother, who was [[Jews|Jewish]], converted to her husband's faith.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-01-22/news/vw-152_1_bernie-goetz |work=Los Angeles Times |first=Joseph |last=McNamara |title=Book Review : Goetz: Anger of a Loner, Rage in the Mean Streets |date=January 22, 1987 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20170310040446/http://articles.latimes.com/1987-01-22/news/vw-152_1_bernie-goetz |archivedate=March 10, 2017 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-01-07/news/mn-11761_1_subway-gunman |work=Los Angeles Times |title=Crime Frustrated Goetz, Neighbors Say |date=January 7, 1985 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20120329084723/http://articles.latimes.com/1985-01-07/news/mn-11761_1_subway-gunman |archivedate=March 29, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>George P. Fletcher, A crime of self-defense: Bernhard Goetz and the Law on Trial, p.10</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/03/03/nyregion/goetz-gets-140550-from-father-s-estate.html |work=The New York Times |title=Goetz Gets $140,550 From Father's Estate |date=March 3, 1988 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170814142358/http://www.nytimes.com/1988/03/03/nyregion/goetz-gets-140550-from-father-s-estate.html |archivedate=August 14, 2017 |df= }}</ref>
While growing up, Goetz lived with his parents and three older siblings [[Upstate New York|upstate]], where his father ran a dairy farm and a bookbinding business.<ref name="Time_1985-04-08">{{cite journal |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,965495,00.html?iid=chix-sphere |title=A Troubled and Troubling Life |journal=Time |date=April 8, 1985 |author=Richard Stengel |author2=Marcia Gauger |author3=Barry Kalb |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130602033237/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,965495,00.html?iid=chix-sphere |archivedate=June 2, 2013 |df= }}</ref> At the age of 12, he was sent to [[Switzerland]], where he and his sister attended boarding school.<ref name="biography.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.biography.com/people/bernhard-goetz-578520|title=Bernhard Goetz|website=Biography.com|accessdate=29 June 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170501200606/http://www.biography.com/people/bernhard-goetz-578520|archivedate=1 May 2017|df=}}</ref> Goetz returned to the United States in 1965 for college, and earned a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[electrical engineering]] and [[nuclear engineering]] from [[New York University]].<ref name="Time_1985-04-08"/> By this time the family had relocated to [[Orlando, Florida]]; Goetz joined them and worked at his father's residential development business. He was briefly married, and after his divorce moved to New York City, where he started an electronics business out of his [[Greenwich Village]] apartment.<ref name="Time_1985-04-08"/>
==Public reaction== "The Subway Vigilante," as Goetz was labeled by [[New York City media]], was front-page news for months, partly due to the repressed passions the incident unleashed in New York and other cities. Public opinion tended to fall into one of three camps: Those in the first camp tended to believe Goetz's version of the incident, that he was aggressively accosted and surrounded by the four men and feared he was about to be beaten and robbed. Those in the second camp tended to believe the version told by the four men, that they were merely panhandling to get some money to play video games. A third camp believed that Goetz had indeed been threatened, but viewed the shooting as an unjustified overreaction.{{citation needed|date = December 2014}}
===Supporters=== Supporters viewed Goetz as a hero for standing up to his attackers and defending himself in an environment where the police were increasingly viewed as ineffective in combating crime.<ref name="NYT_1985-01-07">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/07/nyregion/angry-citizens-in-many-cities-supporting-goetz.html |title=Angry Citizens In Many Cities Supporting Goetz |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 7, 1985 |last=Fein |first=Esther B. |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171128134910/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/07/nyregion/angry-citizens-in-many-cities-supporting-goetz.html |archivedate=November 28, 2017 |df= }}</ref> The [[Guardian Angels]], a volunteer patrol group of mostly black and Hispanic teenagers,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/06/10/nyregion/46th-street-restaurant-row-starts-guardian-angel-patrol.html?pagewanted=all |title=46th Street 'Restaurant Row' Starts Guardian Angel Patrol |newspaper=The New York Times |date=June 10, 1988 |last=Butterfield |first=Fox |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310092734/http://www.nytimes.com/1988/06/10/nyregion/46th-street-restaurant-row-starts-guardian-angel-patrol.html?pagewanted=all |archivedate=March 10, 2016 |df= }}</ref> collected thousands of dollars from subway riders toward a legal defense fund for Goetz.<ref name="TIME_1985-01-25"/> The [[Congress of Racial Equality]] (CORE), a [[civil rights]] organization, supported Goetz.<ref>{{cite news |title=Goetz jury did not endorse vigilantism |work=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution |author=Rick Hampton |date=May 18, 1987}}</ref> Its director, [[Roy Innis]], a member of the [[National Rifle Association]]'s governing board,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=16324652&ft=1&f=5 |title='Ricochet' Goes Behind Scenes of Gun Lobby |date=2007-11-15 |publisher=[[National Public Radio]] |accessdate=2007-11-15 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090629195130/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=16324652&ft=1&f=5 |archivedate=2009-06-29 |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.nrawinningteam.com/bios99/innis.html "Roy Innis re-elected to NRA Board"], NRAwinningteam.com. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013003459/http://www.nrawinningteam.com/bios99/innis.html |date=October 13, 2007 }}</ref> offered to raise defense money, saying Goetz was "the avenger for all of us," and calling for a volunteer force of armed civilians to patrol the streets.<ref name="TIME_1985-01-25">{{cite journal |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,956277-1,00.html |title=Low Profile for a Legend |journal=Time |date=January 25, 1985 |author=John Leo |author2=Jack E. White |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102081858/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,956277-1,00.html |archivedate=November 2, 2012 |df= }}{{subscription required}}</ref>
The prior criminal convictions of three of the four men (and the published accounts of such) prevented them from gaining much sympathy from many people. A special hotline set up by police to seek information was swamped by calls supporting the shooter and calling him a hero.<ref name="NYT_1984-12-30"/><ref name="TIME_1985-01-25"/>
Harvard Professor of Government [[James Q. Wilson]] explained the broad sentiment by saying, "It may simply indicate that there are no more liberals on the crime and law-and-order issue in New York City, because they've all been mugged."<ref name="TIME_1985-01-25"/>
===Other viewpoints=== Some believed the version of the incident as told by the four men – that they were merely panhandling with neither intimidation nor threats of violence. This view was later discredited when Darrell Cabey, who had been paralyzed by Goetz's gunshot twelve years earlier, admitted in a newspaper interview with columnist [[Jimmy Breslin]] that his friends had indeed intended to rob Goetz, who looked like "easy bait".<ref name="NYT_19960418">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/18/nyregion/goetz-defense-opens-calls-jimmy-breslin-and-a-psychiatrist-thencloses.html |title=Goetz Defense Opens, Calls Jimmy Breslin and a Psychiatrist, Then Closes |newspaper=The New York Times |date=April 18, 1996 |last=Hoffman |first=Jan |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170307090647/http://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/18/nyregion/goetz-defense-opens-calls-jimmy-breslin-and-a-psychiatrist-thencloses.html |archivedate=March 7, 2017 |df= }}</ref>
Some saw the incident as racial (with Goetz being white and the four young men black), and the jury verdict as a blow to race relations. [[Benjamin Hooks]], director of the [[NAACP]], said "The jury verdict was inexcusable. [...] It was proven – according to his own statements – that Goetz did the shooting and went far beyond the realm of self-defense. There was no provocation for what he did." Representative [[Floyd Flake]] agreed, saying, "I think that if a black had shot four whites, the cry for the death penalty would have been almost automatic."<ref name="NYT_1987-06-18">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/18/nyregion/blacks-see-goetz-verdict-as-blow-to-race-relations.html |title=Blacks See Goetz Verdict As Blow To Race Relations |newspaper=The New York Times |date=June 18, 1987 |last=Pitt |first=David E. |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161114180653/http://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/18/nyregion/blacks-see-goetz-verdict-as-blow-to-race-relations.html |archivedate=November 14, 2016 |df= }}</ref> Co-counsel for Cabey [[C. Vernon Mason]], a candidate for district attorney who was later disbarred, said Goetz's actions were racist,<ref name="NYT_1987-06-18" /> as did the Rev. [[Al Sharpton]].
Organized demonstrators accused Goetz of genocide.<ref name="LA Times February 7, 1985">{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-02-07/news/mn-5137_1_bernhard-goetz |title=Bail Slashed for Man Who Shot Four on Subway |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=February 7, 1985 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20120127212645/http://articles.latimes.com/1985-02-07/news/mn-5137_1_bernhard-goetz |archivedate=January 27, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Goetz's racial language about criminal activity on 14th Street, allegedly made at a community meeting 18 months before the shooting – "The only way we're going to clean up this street is to get rid of the spics and niggers"<ref name="Friedman"/> – was offered as evidence of racial motivation for the shooting. Black political and religious leaders twice called for Federal [[civil rights]] investigations.<ref name="NYT_1985-01-30">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/30/nyregion/us-attorney-meets-with-blacks-over-request-for-inquiry-on-goetz.html |title=U.S. Attorney Meets With Blacks Over Request For Inquiry On Goetz |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 30, 1985 |last=Chambers |first=Marcia |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171127172726/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/30/nyregion/us-attorney-meets-with-blacks-over-request-for-inquiry-on-goetz.html |archivedate=November 27, 2017 |df= }}</ref>
An investigation by the office of [[U.S. Attorney]] [[Rudolph Giuliani]] determined that the impetus for the shooting had been fear, not race.<ref name="NYT_1987-06-20">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/20/nyregion/naacp-leader-seeks-federal-case-on-goetz.html |title=N.A.A.C.P. Leader Seeks Federal Case On Goetz |newspaper=The New York Times |date=June 20, 1987 |last=Lyall |first=Sarah |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171104122642/http://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/20/nyregion/naacp-leader-seeks-federal-case-on-goetz.html |archivedate=November 4, 2017 |df= }}</ref> In an interview with [[Stone Phillips]] of ''[[Dateline NBC]]'', Goetz later admitted that his fear was enhanced due to the fact that the alleged muggers were black.<ref>{{cite web |title=Stone Phillips: 15 Years of Dateline |author=Phillips, Stone |authorlink=Stone Phillips |publisher=MSNBC |date=July 2, 2007 |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/19562622/ns/dateline_nbc/t/stone-phillips-years-dateline/}}</ref>
==Grand juries== [[New York County District Attorney|Manhattan District Attorney]] [[Robert Morgenthau]] asked a [[grand jury]] to [[indictment|indict]] Goetz on four counts of attempted murder, four of [[assault]], four of reckless endangerment, and one of criminal possession of a weapon.<ref name="NYT_1985-01-26">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/26/nyregion/grand-jury-votes-to-indict-goetz-only-on-gun-possession-charges.html |title=Grand Jury Votes To Indict Goetz Only On Gun Possession Charges |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 26, 1985 |last=Chambers |first=Marcia |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202070526/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/26/nyregion/grand-jury-votes-to-indict-goetz-only-on-gun-possession-charges.html |archivedate=February 2, 2017 |df= }}</ref> Because they would have to be granted [[immunity from prosecution]], neither Goetz nor the four men he shot were called to testify. The 23 jurors heard witnesses, considered the police report of the shooting, and studied [[transcript (law)|transcripts]] and tapes of the sometimes conflicting statements Goetz made to police in New Hampshire.<ref name="NYT_1985-02-28">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/02/28/nyregion/goetz-spoke-to-one-youth-then-shot-again-police-say.html |title=Goetz Spoke To One Youth, Then Shot Again, Police Say |newspaper=The New York Times |date=February 28, 1985 |last=Chambers |first=Marcia |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202070512/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/02/28/nyregion/goetz-spoke-to-one-youth-then-shot-again-police-say.html |archivedate=February 2, 2017 |df= }}</ref><ref name="NYT_1985-03-01">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/03/01/nyregion/morgenthau-says-goetz-case-may-go-to-2d-grand-jury.html |title=Morgenthau Says Goetz Case May Go To 2D Grand Jury |newspaper=The New York Times |date=March 1, 1985 |last=Roberts |first=Sam |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202070931/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/03/01/nyregion/morgenthau-says-goetz-case-may-go-to-2d-grand-jury.html |archivedate=February 2, 2017 |df= }}</ref> The jury refused to indict Goetz on the more serious charges, voting indictments only for unlawful gun possession – one count of criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree, for carrying in public the loaded unlicensed gun used in the subway shooting, and two counts of possession in the fourth degree, for keeping two other unlicensed handguns in his home.<ref name="NYT_1985-01-26"/> The case was assigned to Judge Stephen Crane.
The shootings initially drew wide support from a public fearful and frustrated with rising crime rates and the state of the criminal justice system.<ref name="NYT_1985-01-07" /><ref name="NEWS_2001-11-08">{{cite news |url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2001-11-08/news/18357738_1_gunman-new-yorkers-subway-vigilante |title=Quality Of Life The Subway Vigilante, December 1984 – January 1985 Chapter 463 |newspaper=Daily News |date=November 8, 2001 |last=Maeder |first=Jay}}</ref> A month after the grand jury's decision, a report summarizing statements Goetz made to police became public, indicating he had fired one shot at each of the four men, then checked their condition, and seeing no blood on the fourth, said "You don't look so bad, here's another" and fired again.<ref name="NYT_1985-02-28" /> The media now wrote of a change in the public mood<ref name="TIME_1985-03-25">{{cite journal |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,964133,00.html |title=New Evidence |journal=Time |date=March 25, 1985 |author=Richard Stengel |author2=Marcia Gauger |author3=John F. Stacks |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071109180702/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,964133,00.html |archivedate=November 9, 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref name="TV GUIDE_1985-27-25">{{cite journal |url=http://www.triroc.com/bg/tvguidebgoetz.pdf |title=But Where Were The Facts? |journal=TV Guide |date=July 27, 1985 |author1=Edwin Diamond |author2=Claire Tallarico |author3=George Gelish |author4=Joanna Otto |author5=Karen Wishod |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613034152/http://www.triroc.com/bg/tvguidebgoetz.pdf |archivedate=June 13, 2011 |df= }}</ref> and demanded that Goetz be tried on the attempted murder and assault charges while suggesting approaches that would allow Morgenthau to convene a new grand jury.<ref name="NYT_1985-03-01ed">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/03/01/opinion/you-don-t-look-so-bad-if-criminal-justice-system-can-t-protect-new-yorkers-why.html |title='You Don't Look So Bad ...' If the criminal justice system can't protect New Yorkers, why shouldn't they try to defend themselves? That was the question first raised by the tormenting case of Bernhard Goetz. Mr. Goetz's own account of the incident, just released, changes the question: When does defending yourself turn into appointing yourself judge, jury and executioner? It is a question that demands a prompt answer – in a trial. |newspaper=The New York Times |date=March 1, 1985 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171126125628/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/03/01/opinion/you-don-t-look-so-bad-if-criminal-justice-system-can-t-protect-new-yorkers-why.html |archivedate=November 26, 2017 |df= }}</ref> Public figures including New York Governor [[Mario Cuomo]] raised questions based on the police summary. Senator [[Arlen Specter]] of Pennsylvania called for a special prosecutor.<ref name="NYT_1985-03-01"/>
Stating that he had a new witness, Morgenthau obtained Judge Crane's authorization<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.triroc.com/BHG/NYSvBG.htm |title=THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF YORK against BERNHARD GOETZ |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230232209/http://www.triroc.com/BHG/NYSvBG.htm |archivedate=2013-12-30 |df= }}</ref> to convene a second grand jury, which heard testimony by Canty and Ramseur and indicted Goetz on charges of attempted murder, assault, reckless endangerment and weapons possession.<ref name="NYT_1987-06-17">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/17/nyregion/goets-cleared-subway-attack-gun-count-upheld-acquittal-won-shooting-4-youths.html |title=Goetz Is Cleared In Subway Attack; Gun Count Upheld; Acquittal Won In Shooting Of 4 Youths – Prison Term Possible On Weapon Charge |newspaper=The New York Times |date=June 17, 1987 |last=Johnson |first=Kirk |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171104113856/http://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/17/nyregion/goets-cleared-subway-attack-gun-count-upheld-acquittal-won-shooting-4-youths.html |archivedate=November 4, 2017 |df= }}</ref> Judge Crane later granted a motion by Goetz to dismiss the new indictments, based on alleged errors in the prosecutor's instructions to the jury regarding Goetz's defense of [[Justification (jurisprudence)|justification]] for the use of [[deadly force]].
