hundreds more" and called "for an unconditional end to Israel's inhuman [[Blockade of the Gaza Strip|siege of Gaza]] and its brutal [[Palestinian territories|occupation of the West Bank]] which has destroyed the lives of generations of Palestinians."{{cite news |last= |first= |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/apr/03/call-for-an-end-to-the-siege-of-gaza|title= Call for an end to the siege of Gaza |work= |location= |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=3 April 2018|accessdate=1 June 2018}} In May, JVL with members of Free Speech on Israel produced a definition of antisemitism as: "Antisemitism is a form of racism: hatred, hostility, discrimination or prejudice against Jews because they are Jews. It may be manifested in violence; denial of rights; direct, indirect or institutional discrimination; prejudice-based behaviour; or verbal or written statements. Such manifestations draw on stereotypes – characteristics which all Jews are presumed to share."{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://jewishnews.timesofisrael.com/jewish-voice-for-labour-offer-new-anti-semitism-definition/|title=Jewish Voice for Labour offer new anti-Semitism definition|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Jewish News]]''|date=17 May 2018|accessdate=17 May 2018}} In July, JVL said in a statement about Labour's code of conduct that defines antisemitism which was adopted by the [[National Executive Committee]] (NEC) for the purposes of disciplinary cases brought before the National Constitutional Committee that it "offers a constructive framework for moving forward in this difficult area" and it encouraged "free speech on issues to do with Israel and its treatment of the Palestinians, and with Zionism" but "much will depend on how this code of conduct is applied in practice, particularly in disciplinary cases. We are cautiously optimistic."{{cite news |last=Winstanley|first=Asa|url=https://www.electronicintifada.net/blogs/asa-winstanley/calling-israel-racist-isnt-anti-semitic-rules-uk-labour|title=Calling Israel racist isn’t anti-Semitic, rules UK Labour|work= |location= |publisher=''[[The Electronic Intifada]]''|date=7 July 2018|accessdate=1 August 2018}}{{better source|This is a blogpost|date=November 2018}} In the same month, the organisation was a signatory of 41 Jewish organisations in 15 countries, including six based in the UK criticising the IHRA definition.{{cite web |url=https://jewishvoiceforpeace.org/first-ever-40-jewish-groups-worldwide-oppose-equating-antisemitism-with-criticism-of-israel/|title=First-ever: 40+ Jewish groups worldwide oppose equating antisemitism with criticism of Israel|publisher=Jewish Voice for Peace|date=17 July 2018|accessdate=1 November 2018}}{{cite news |last= |first= |url=https://www.commondreams.org/newswire/2018/07/17/first-ever-over-30-jewish-groups-worldwide-oppose-equating-antisemitism|title=First Ever: Over 30 Jewish Groups Worldwide Oppose Equating Antisemitism With Criticism of Israel|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Common Dreams]]''|date=17 July 2018|accessdate=1 November 2018}} In August, the organisation called for support of Labour's code of conduct{{cite news |last=Tobin|first=Sam|url=https://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/article/chris-williamson-calls-labour-supporters-backthecode-twitterstorm|title=Chris Williamson calls for Labour supporters to #backthecode in Twitterstorm|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Morning Star (British newspaper)|Morning Star]]''|date=19 August 2018|accessdate=1 October 2018}} and for the NEC to resist adopting the IHRA examples of antisemitism as it fell short of providing "a clear and unambiguous statement based on attitudes to Jews as Jews, not attitudes to a country, Israel".{{cite news |last= |first= |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-45402036|title=Labour's ruling body holds crunch anti-Semitism talks|work= |location= |publisher=''[[BBC News]]''|date=4 September 2018|accessdate=1 October 2018}} In August, JVL complained to the [[BBC]] director-general [[Tony Hall, Baron Hall of Birkenhead|Baron Tony Hall]] and news and current affairs director [[Francesca Unsworth]] by criticising and demonstrating against the BBC's "lack of impartiality and inaccuracies" and "biased" coverage of Labour MP [[Margaret Hodge]]'s allegations of antisemitism against Jeremy Corbyn.{{cite news |last=Sabin|first=Lamiat|url=https://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/article/bbcs-‘lack-impartiality-and-inaccuracies’-reporting-hodges-claims-against-corbyn-condemned|title=BBC cornered over 'biased' coverage of anti-semitism row|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Morning Star (British newspaper)|Morning Star]]''|date=7 August 2018|accessdate=21 August 2018}}{{cite news |last=Blakelock|first=Pamela|url=https://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/article/letter-bbc-about-biased-and-inaccurate-reporting-anti-semitism-allegations-towards-jeremy-0|title=Letter to the BBC about biased and inaccurate reporting of anti-semitism allegations towards Jeremy Corbyn|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Morning Star (British newspaper)|Morning Star]]''|date=7 August 2018|accessdate=1 October 2018}} In September, JVL jointly with Free Speech on Israel published a declaration on antisemitic misconduct. JVL contributed to the consultation on Labour's code of conduct rejecting suggestions that comparisons between Israel and "features of pre-war [[Nazi Germany]]" or [[apartheid]]-era South Africa were "inherently antisemitic", arguing that "Drawing such parallels can undoubtedly cause offence; but potent historical events and experiences are always key reference points in political debate. Such comparisons are only anti-Semitic if they show prejudice, hostility or hatred against Jews as Jews."{{cite news |last= |first= |url=https://jewishnews.timesofisrael.com/expelled-activist-tells-jvl-meeting-that-witchhunt-is-plot-to-topple-corbyn/|title=Expelled activist tells JVL meeting that ‘witchhunt’ is plot to ‘topple’ Corbyn|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Jewish News]]''|date=25 September 2018|accessdate=1 October 2018}} Their guidelines on antisemitism include questions of Israel and Zionism such as "Jews, Israelis and Zionists are separate categories that are too frequently conflated by both supporters and critics of Israel. This conflation can be anti-Semitic. Holding all Jews responsible for the actions of the Israeli government is anti-Semitic. Many Jews are not Zionist."{{cite news |last=Gill|first=Joe|url=https://www.middleeasteye.net/columns/h-did-you-hear-about-anti-semitic-bomb-threat-labour-conference-1771265636|title=Labour bomb threat: When pro-Palestine Jews are targeted, the media is silent|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Middle East Eye]]''|date=1 October 2018|accessdate=4 October 2018}} The organisation also questioned whether "discussion and education, rather than a formal disciplinary approach" could be more appropriate in some cases of antisemitism. In September, at the [[Labour Party Conference (UK)#2018_Liverpool|Labour Party Conference]], JVL hosted two fringe events: "Israel/Palestine: Antisemitism" and "Fighting The Far Right".{{cite news |last=Chaplain|first=Chloe|url=https://www.inews.co.uk/news/politics/labour-party-conference-highlights-schedule-full-events-world-transformed/|title=Labour party conference highlights: The essential details of the event in Liverpool|work= |location= |publisher=''[[iNews]]''|date=21 September 2018|accessdate=1 October 2018}} JVL also organised and hosted the premier of the documentary film ''The Political Lynching of Jackie Walker'' where 200 people were evacuated after a bomb threat.{{cite news |last1=Thomas|first1=Joe|last2=Kirkham|first2=Jenny|url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/film-screening-hosted-jewish-voices-15200721|title=Labour party conference highlights: The essential details of the event in Liverpool|work= |location=Liverpool|publisher=''[[Liverpool Echo]]''|date=25 September 2018|accessdate=1 October 2018}}{{cite news |last=Rawlinson|first=Kevin|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/sep/25/jewish-event-at-labour-conference-abandoned-after-bomb-scare|title=Jewish event at Labour conference abandoned after bomb scare|work= |location= |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=25 September 2018|accessdate=1 October 2018}} In a statement the organisation said the film "is an incisive and chilling exposé of attempts to silence critics of Israel, in particular those who support the socialist project of Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn. It connects the global struggle against racism and the far right with the [[Human rights in the State of Palestine|Palestinian cause]]."{{cite news |last= |first= |url=https://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/article/jewish-voice-labour-film-screening-evacuated-after-bomb-threat|title=Jewish Voice for Labour film screening evacuated after bomb threat|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Morning Star (British newspaper)|Morning Star]]''|date=26 September 2018|accessdate=1 October 2018}} ==See also== *[[Independent Jewish Voices]] *[[Jewish Socialists' Group]] *[[Socialist society (Labour Party)]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.jewishvoiceforlabour.org.uk/}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jewish Voice for Labour}} [[Category:2017 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2017]] [[Category:Jewish political organizations]] [[Category:Jewish organisations based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Opposition to antisemitism]] [[Category:Non-governmental organizations involved in the Israeli–Palestinian conflict]] [[Category:Organisations associated with the Labour Party (UK)]]

- Jamie Micklethwaite, [http://www.newsshopper.co.uk/news/12910415.Sydenham_and_Forest_Hill_hustings_cancelled_due_to_presence_of__far_right_wing__candidate/ "Sydenham and Forest Hill hustings cancelled after candidates allegedly refuse to appear at event with Liberty GB member George Whale"], ''News Shopper'', 27 April 2015
- Lizzie Dearden, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/former-ukip-candidate-and-pegida-uk-leader-paul-weston-says-muslims-should-not-hold-political-power-a6856086.html "Former Ukip candidate and Pegida UK leader says 'Muslims should not hold political power' and claims Syrian refugees do not exist"], ''The Independent'', 5 February 2016
- Jess Commons, [http://www.thedebrief.co.uk/things-to-do/tv-and-film/why-you-need-to-watch-the-documentary-exploring-whether-britain-actually-is-racist-20151054648 "Why You Need To Watch The Documentary Exploring If Britain Actually Is Racist"], ''The Debrief'' 5 October 2015
- Mike Lockley, [http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/local-news/radio-host-cleared-over-scumbag-7069475 "Radio host cleared over 'scumbag' tweet jibe to Musilm campaigner "], ''Birmingham Mail'', 4 May 2014 | membership = | youth_wing = }} '''Liberty Great Britain''' or '''Liberty GB''' was a [[Far-right politics|far-right]]{{citation|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/dead-murdered-labour-mp-batley-and-spen-by-election-bnp-politician-jack-buckby-a7089966.html|title=Jo Cox: Former BNP politician Jack Buckby to contest by-election for murdered MP's Batley and Spen seat|accessdate=19 June 2016|author=Siobhan Fenton|work=[[The Independent]]}} British nationalist [[political party]] that described itself as [[counter-jihad]].{{cite journal|date=4 September 2015|title=A Day in the "Swamp": Understanding Discourse in the Online Counter-Jihad Nebula|journal=Democracy and Security|volume=11|issue=3|pages=248–274|doi=10.1080/17419166.2015.1067612|last1=Lee|first1=Benjamin}} [http://eprints.lancs.ac.uk/78286/1/a_day_in_the_swamp_author_sub.pdf Open source version] It was registered with the [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]] by [[Paul Weston (politician)|Paul Weston]] and George Whale on 5 March 2013.[https://pefonline.electoralcommission.org.uk/Search/EntitySearch.aspx Electoral Commission searchable registration database]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Its three candidates in the [[European Parliament election, 2014 (United Kingdom)|2014 European Parliament election]] in the [[South East England (European Parliament constituency)|South East England constituency]] received 2,414 votes (0.11%).[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/politics/eu-regions/E15000008 "Vote 2014 - South East"], ''BBC News'', 26 May 2014 Paul Weston dissolved the party in November 2017, choosing instead to back [[Anne Marie Waters]]' new party, [[For Britain]].{{cite web|url=https://libertygb.org.uk/news/important-announcement-paul-weston-concerning-future-liberty-gb|title=An Important Announcement from Paul Weston Concerning the Future of Liberty GB - Liberty GB|website=libertygb.org.uk}} Weston is a former member of the [[UK Independence Party]] (UKIP), and was that party's candidate in [[Cities of London and Westminster (UK Parliament constituency)|Cities of London and Westminster]] at the 2010 general election.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/english-defence-league-prepares-to-storm-local-elections-6267740.html|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|title=English Defence League prepares to storm local elections|author=Kevin Rawlinson|date=25 November 2011|accessdate=13 December 2011}} He left UKIP over what he described as its failure to address issues related to [[Islam in the United Kingdom|Islam in Britain]], and took over the [[British Freedom Party]] (BFP) from Peter Mullins. That party formed an alliance with the far-right [[English Defence League]]. Weston left the BFP in 2013. He has predicted that within 20 years there will be a war in Britain between the white working class and immigrants. He is married to a [[Romanians|Romanian]], and claims to have been a [[Deep diving|deep sea diver]], a pilot in Africa and a property developer in the [[Czech Republic]].Martin Evans, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/10792895/Election-candidate-arrested-over-Churchill-speech.html "Election candidate arrested over Churchill speech"], ''The Telegraph'', 28 April 2014 Liberty GB was anti-immigration, anti-fundamentalist Islam and traditionalist.Sonia Gable, [http://www.searchlightmagazine.com/blogs/searchlight-blog/liberty-it-isn%E2%80%99t "Liberty it isn’t"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503134607/http://www.searchlightmagazine.com/blogs/searchlight-blog/liberty-it-isn%E2%80%99t |date=3 May 2014}} ''[[Searchlight (magazine)|Searchlight]]'', 12 March 2013 The group's Facebook page described it as "patriotic counter-jihad party for Christian civilisation, Western rights and freedoms, British culture, animal welfare and capitalism". ==2014 European election== Liberty GB stood three candidates in the [[European Parliament election, 2014 (United Kingdom)|2014 European Parliament election]] in the [[South East England (European Parliament constituency)|South East England constituency]]: Weston, Enza Ferreri (Liberty GB's media officer) and [[Jack Buckby]] (Liberty GB's outreach officer).[http://ukpollingreport.co.uk/2015guide/south-east-european-candidates-2014/ South East Euro Candidates 2014], UK Polling Report Buckby founded the "National Culturists" while at university in [[Liverpool]] in 2012.Matthew Francey, [https://www.vice.com/en_uk/read/jack-buckby-is-proud-to-be-britains-next-nick-griffin Jack Buckby is proud to be Britain's next Nick Griffin"], ''Vice'', 20 February 2013 It received 2,414 votes (0.11%), placing it 14th of the 15 parties contesting the election. ===Paul Weston arrest=== On 26 April 2014, Weston was arrested while addressing passers-by outside [[Winchester]] Guildhall. A member of the public complained to police and he was detained after failing to move on under a dispersal order. He was further arrested on suspicion of religious or racial harassment.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-27186573 "Euro candidate Paul Weston arrested over Islam remarks"], ''BBC News'', 28 April 2014 Weston's speech quoted from [[Winston Churchill]]'s 1899 book ''[[The River War]]'', about Churchill's experiences as a British army officer in [[Sudan]]; the passage quoted was critical of [[Islam]]. Weston is a former [[UK Independence Party]] (UKIP) candidate who left that party over what he described as its failure to address issues related to [[Islam in the United Kingdom|Islam in Britain]], and then joined the [[British Freedom Party]].{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/10792895/Election-candidate-arrested-over-Churchill-speech.html |title=Election candidate arrested over Churchill speech |first=Martin |last=Evan |date=28 April 2014}} ==Liberty GB radio host trial== Tim Burton, a radio presenter who was a member of Liberty GB, was acquitted of charges of racially aggravated harassment on 4 May 2014 at Birmingham magistrates' court. He had tweeted comments about Fiyaz Mughal [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]], a Muslim campaigner of [[Tell MAMA UK]].Mike Lockley, [http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/local-news/radio-host-cleared-over-scumbag-7069475 "Radio host cleared over 'scumbag' tweet jibe to Muslim campaigner"], ''Birmingham Mail'', 4 May 2014 ==2016 Batley and Spen by-election== Following the [[Killing of Jo Cox|killing of the incumbent]] Labour MP [[Jo Cox]], Liberty GB contested the [[Batley and Spen (UK Parliament constituency)|Batley and Spen]] by-election (the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]], [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]] and UKIP declined to contest it). The party's candidate was Jack Buckby, who was a member of the youth division of the [[British National Party]] (BNP) under [[Nick Griffin]] before leaving the party. He says he left because he believed that the BNP was too racist.{{cite news|last1=Cowburn|first1=Ashley|title=Jo Cox: Liberty GB Move to Contest Labour MP's Former Seat Branded 'Obscene' and 'Contemptible'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/jo-cox-death-labour-mp-seat-batley-and-spen-by-election-liberty-gb-bnp-jack-buckby-a7091141.html|website=www.independent.co.uk|accessdate=21 June 2016|date=20 June 2016}} Buckby polled just over 1% of the vote; he lost his deposit, as did all the candidates except the winner, the Labour candidate [[Tracy Brabin]]. ==Electoral performance== ===[[United Kingdom general election, 2015|General election, 7 May 2015]]=== The party contested three constituencies, obtaining a total of 418 votes. {| class="wikitable" ! ''Hudersfield Examiner'', 21 October 2016 |} ==See also== *[[Pegida UK]] *[[English Defence League]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://libertygb.org.uk}} {{English Defence League}} {{UK far right}} [[Category:Counter-jihad]] [[Category:2013 establishments in England]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2013]] [[Category:Far-right political parties in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Nationalist parties in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Eurosceptic parties in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Far-right politics in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:UK Independence Party breakaway groups]] [[Category:Opposition to Islam in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Parties that campaigned for leave during the United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 2017]] [[Category:2017 disestablishments in the United Kingdom]]

In recent years, several [[political parties]] were founded that have as their main goal the improvement of [[animal welfare]] and the recognition of '''[[animal rights]]''':
== Political parties ==
=== Europe === * The [[Animal Welfare Party of Germany|Human Environment Animal Welfare Party]] ({{lang-de|Partei Mensch Umwelt Tierschutz}}, in short: ''{{lang|de|Tierschutzpartei}}'') was founded in [[Germany]], in 1993. * The [[Party for the Animals]] ({{lang-nl|Partij voor de Dieren}}) was founded in the [[Netherlands]] in 2002. It is represented in parliament with five seats from 2017. In 2012 the representatives were {{lang|nl|[[Marianne Thieme]]}} and {{lang|nl|[[Esther Ouwehand]]}}. * The [[Animalist Party Against Mistreatment to Animals]] ({{lang-es|PACMA}}, founded in 2003 as ''{{lang|es|Partido Antitaurino Contra el Maltrato Animal}}'', in 2011 renamed to ''{{lang|es|Partido Animalista Contra el Maltrato Animal}}''). * The [[Animal Welfare Party]] was launched in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] in 2006. * The [[Animal Protection Party]] was founded in [[England]] in 2008. * The {{lang|it|[http://www.partitoanimalistaeuropeo.it/ Partito Animalista Europeo]}} was founded in [[Italy]] in 2006. * The [[Italian Animal Welfare Party]] was founded in [[Italy]] in 2006. * The [[People-Animals-Nature]] (PAN) formerly Party for Animals and Nature ({{lang-pt|Partido pelos Animais e pela Natureza}}) was founded in [[Portugal]] in 2009. It is represented in [[Assembleia da República|parliament]] by André Silva elected for the Lisbon electoral circle in the [[Portuguese legislative election, 2015|legislative elections of 2015]]. * {{lang|da|[[Fokus (party)|Fokus]]}} was founded in [[Denmark]] in 2010, originally as a splinter group from the [[Danish People's Party]]. * The [http://www.tierpartei.ch/ Party for the animals Switzerland] ({{lang-de|Tierpartei Schweiz}}, {{lang-fr|Parti suisse pour les animaux}}, {{lang-it|Partito svizzero per gli animali}}, {{lang-rm|Partida svizra d'animals}}) was founded in [[Switzerland]] in 2010. * The Party {{lang|it|EcoAnimalista}} ([https://www.facebook.com/PartitoEcoAnimalistaUfficiale?ref=br_rs EcoAnimalista Facebook]) was founded in [[Italy]] in 2012. * The Animals' Party ({{lang-sv|[http://www.djurensparti.se/ Djurens parti]}}) was founded in [[Sweden]] in 2014. * The [http://www.animalpartycyprus.org Animal Party Cyprus] ({{lang-el|Κομμα για τα Ζωα Κυπρου}}) was founded in 2014. * The [http://www.euroanimal7.org/ Euro Animal 7] [[Europe]]an group founded in 2014. * [http://eop.fi/ The Animal Justice Party of Finland] was founded in 2015. * The French [https://parti-animaliste.fr/ Animal Party] was founded in 2016. * {{lang|de|[[V-Partei³]]}} ({{lang-de|V-Partei³ – Partei für Veränderung, Vegetarier und Veganer}}, Party for Change, Vegetarians and Vegans) is a [[Political parties in Germany|German political party]] founded in 2016. * The Belgian [https://dieranimal.be/ DierAnimal] was founded in 2017. * [https://vgpt.dk/ Veganerpartiet] was founded in [[Denmark]] in 2018.
=== North America === * The [[Animal Alliance Environment Voters Party of Canada]] was formed in 2005 by two organizations, the Animal Alliance of Canada and Environment Voters. Both parent organizations have been vocal in opposition to the seal hunt in Newfoundland and Labrador, fur farming, trapping, and bear hunting. The party is led by Liz White, a Toronto-based animal rights advocate. * The [[Humane Party]] was founded in the [[United States]] in 2009. * The [https://web.archive.org/web/20150801045238/http://animalrightsparty.org/ Animal Rights Party USA] was founded in the [[United States]] in 2011. It is modeled after the Dutch Party for the Animals (PvdD). Like the PvdD, it is a political animal welfare organization that focuses on improving animal welfare and animal rights, and solving related environmental problems.
=== Oceania === * The [[Animal Justice Party]] was founded in [[Australia]] in 2010. It is represented in the [[New South Wales Legislative Council]] with one seat.

This is a '''list of government surveillance projects''' and related databases throughout the world.
== International == [[File:Boundless-heatmap-large-001.jpg|thumb|300px|Snapshot of [[Boundless Informant]]'s global map of data collection]] * '''[[ECHELON]]''': A [[signals intelligence]] (SIGINT) collection and analysis network operated on behalf of the five signatory states to the [[UKUSA Agreement|UKUSA Security Agreement]].
=== European Union === * '''[[Data Retention Directive]]''': A directive requiring EU member states to store citizens' telecommunications data for six to 24 months and allowing police and security agencies to request access from a court to details such as IP address and time of use of every email, phone call, and text message sent or received. * '''[[INDECT]]''': Research project funded by the [[European Union]] to develop surveillance methods (e.g. processing of CCTV camera data streams) for the monitoring of abnormal behaviours in an [[urban area|urban]] environment.<ref>Welcome to INDECT homepage — indect-home. [http://www.indect-project.eu/] Retrieved 16 June 2013.</ref> * '''[[Schengen Information System]]''': A database kept for [[national security]] and [[law enforcement]] purposes.
== National ==
=== Australia === {{Main article|Mass surveillance in Australia}} * In August 2014 it was reported<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/digital-life/digital-life-news/telstra-found-divulging-web-browsing-histories-to-lawenforcement-agencies-without-a-warrant-20140820-106112.html|title=Telstra found divulging web browsing histories to law-enforcement agencies without a warrant|author=Ben Grubb|date=20 August 2014|publisher=''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]''}}</ref> that law-enforcement agencies had been accessing Australians' web browsing histories via [[internet provider]]s such as [[Telstra]] without a warrant. * It was reported<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.southsearepublic.org/article/838/read/wiretapping_australia/|title=Wiretapping Australia|year=2003}}</ref> that Australia had issued 75% more wiretap warrants in 2003 than the US did and this was 26 times greater than the US on a per capita basis.
=== China === {{Main article|Mass surveillance in China}} * '''[[Golden Shield Project]]''': Also known as the "Great Firewall of China", it is a [[Internet censorship in the People's Republic of China|censorship]] and [[surveillance]] project operated by the [[Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China|Ministry of Public Security]] (MPS) division of the [[Government of China|government of the People's Republic of China]]. The project was initiated in 1998 and began operations in November 2003.<ref name="radiofreeasia">{{cite web|title=How China’s Internet Police Control Speech on the Internet|url=http://www.rfa.org/english/commentaries/china_internet-11242008134108.html|publisher=[[Radio Free Asia]]|accessdate=11 June 2013|quote=China’s police authorities spent the three years between 2003 and 2006 completing the massive “Golden Shield Project.” Not only did over 50 percent of China’s policing agencies get on the Internet, there is also an agency called the Public Information Network Security and Monitoring Bureau, which boasts a huge number of technologically advanced and well-equipped network police. These are all the direct products of the Golden Shield Project.}}</ref> * '''Monitoring Bureau'''<ref name="radiofreeasia"/> * '''Public Information Network Security'''<ref name="radiofreeasia"/>
=== France === [[File:EMERAUDE - Domme.jpg|thumb|right|[[DGSE]] base near [[Domme, Dordogne|Domme]] in southwestern France]] * '''[[Frenchelon]]''': A data collection and analysis network operated by the French [[Directorate-General for External Security]].<ref>{{cite web|title=La France se met à l'espionnage|url=http://reseau.echelon.free.fr/reseau.echelon/espionnage_francais.htm|publisher=[[Free (ISP)]]|accessdate=11 June 2013|language=French|quote=Frenchelon (ou French Echelon) est le surnom donné au réseau d'écoute de la DGSE. Le véritable nom de ce système d'écoute n'est pas connu (contrairement à ce que nous expliquions, ce n'est pas Emeraude)}}</ref>
=== Germany === * '''[[Nachrichtendienstliches Informationssystem]]''': a searchable database operated by the German security agency [[Bundesamt für Verfassungsschutz]] (BfV).<ref>{{cite web|title=Datenschutzbeauftragte warnen vor Volltextsuche bei Verfassungsschutz und Polizei|url=http://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Datenschutzbeauftragte-warnen-vor-Volltextsuche-bei-Verfassungsschutz-und-Polizei-1131172.html|publisher=[[Heise Online]]|accessdate=20 December 2013|language=German}}</ref> * '''[[Project 6]]''': a [[global surveillance]] project jointly operated by the German intelligence agencies [[Bundesnachrichtendienst]] (BND) and [[Bundesamt für Verfassungsschutz]] (BfV) in close cooperation with the U.S. [[Central Intelligence Agency]] (CIA).<ref name="p6spiegel">{{cite web|author1=Matthias Gebauer |author2=Hubert Gude |author3=Veit Medick |author4=Jörg Schindler |author5=Fidelius Schmid |title=CIA Worked With BND and BfV In Neuss on Secret Project|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/cia-worked-with-bnd-and-bfv-in-neuss-on-secret-project-a-921254.html|publisher=''[[Der Spiegel]]''|accessdate=20 December 2013}}</ref>
=== India === {{Further information|Mass surveillance in India}} * '''[[Central Monitoring System]]''' (CMS): A data collection system similar to the NSA's [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]] program.<ref>{{cite web|title=India's centralised monitoring system comes under scanner, reckless and irresponsible usage is chilling|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/1845205/report-india-s-centralised-monitoring-system-comes-under-scanner-reckless-and-irresponsible-usage-is-chilling|publisher=''[[Daily News and Analysis]]''|accessdate=12 June 2013}}</ref> It enables the [[Government of India]] to listen to phone conversations, intercept [[e-mail]]s and text messages, monitor posts on [[social networking service]] and track searches on [[Google]].<ref>{{cite news|title=India sets up elaborate system to tap phone calls, e-mail|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2013/06/20/india-surveillance-idINL3N0EV1WT20130620|publisher=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=28 June 2013|quote=The new system will allow the government to listen to and tape phone conversations, read e-mails and text messages, monitor posts on Facebook, Twitter or LinkedIn and track searches on Google of selected targets, according to interviews with two other officials involved in setting up the new surveillance programme, human rights activists and cyber experts.|date=20 June 2013}}</ref> * '''[[DRDO NETRA]]''': Network that is capable of tracking online communications on a real time basis by harvesting data from various [[voice-over-IP]] services, including [[Skype]] and [[Google Talk]]. It is operated by the [[Research and Analysis Wing]]. * '''[[NATGRID]]''': An intelligence grid that links the databases of several departments and ministries of the Government of India.
=== Russia === * '''[[SORM]]''': A technical system used by the [[Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation]] to monitor [[internet]] and [[telephone]] communication. * '''[[Yarovaya Law]]''' is an anti-terrorist legislation that includes requirement to store all voice and text messaging data, as well as providing cryptographic [[Backdoor (computing)|backdoors]] for security services.
=== Sweden === * '''[[Titan traffic database]]''': A [[database]] established by the [[Swedish National Defence Radio Establishment]] (Swedish: Försvarets radioanstalt, FRA) where [[call detail record]]s (CDRs) of [[telephony]] and [[internet]] [[traffic]] and [[Database transaction|transaction]] data (IPDRs) concerning international telecommunications are stored.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} * '''[[X-Keyscore]]''': A system used by the United States National Security Agency for searching and analysing internet data about foreign nationals. FRA has been granted access to the program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.svt.se/ug/article1666993.svt|title=FRA har tillgång till kontroversiellt övervakningssystem|first=SVT|last=Nyheter|publisher=}}</ref>
=== Switzerland === *'''[[Onyx (interception system)|Onyx]]''': A data gathering system maintained by several [[Swiss intelligence agencies]] to monitor military and civilian communications, such as [[e-mails]], [[fax|telefax]] and telephone calls. In 2001, Onyx received its second nomination for the ironically-named "[[Big Brother Awards|Big Brother Award]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=Big Brother Awards Schweiz: Onyx zum zweiten|url=http://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Big-Brother-Awards-Schweiz-Onyx-zum-zweiten-49387.html|publisher=Heise.de|accessdate=28 June 2013|language=German}}</ref>
=== United Kingdom === {{Further information |Mass surveillance in the United Kingdom}} * '''[[Impact Nominal Index]]''': The Impact Nominal Index or INI is a computer system that enables the UK police force to establish whether other relevant authorities are holding information regarding a person of interest.<ref>{{cite web|title=THE IMPACT NOMINAL INDEX (INI)|url=http://www.warwickshire.police.uk/onlineservices/INIfolder|publisher=[[Warwickshire Police]]|accessdate=24 June 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130708091252/http://www.warwickshire.police.uk/onlineservices/INIfolder|archivedate=8 July 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * '''[[Interception Modernisation Programme]]''': An initiative to extend the [[UK government]]'s capability to [[lawful interception|lawfully intercept]] and store [[communications data]] in a central database.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2008/10/07/detica_interception_modernisation/|title=Spy chiefs plot £12bn IT spree for comms überdatabase|first=Christopher|last=Williams|date=7 October 2008|publisher=The Register}}</ref> * '''[[Mastering the Internet]]''' (MTI): A clandestine [[mass surveillance]] program led by the British intelligence agency [[GCHQ]]. Data gathered by the GCHQ include the contents of [[email]] messages, entries on the social networking platform [[Facebook]] and the [[web browsing history]] of internet users.<ref>{{cite news|title=GCHQ taps fibre-optic cables for secret access to world's communications|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/jun/21/gchq-cables-secret-world-communications-nsa|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|accessdate=21 June 2013|quote=This includes recordings of phone calls, the content of email messages, entries on Facebook and the history of any internet user's access to websites – all of which is deemed legal, even though the warrant system was supposed to limit interception to a specified range of targets.|location=London|first1=Ewen|last1=MacAskill|first2=Julian|last2=Borger|first3=Nick|last3=Hopkins|date=21 June 2013}}</ref> * '''[[United Kingdom National DNA Database|UK National DNA Database]]''' (NDNAD): It is also the oldest national DNA database in the world.<ref name="ncbihelen"/> Since its establishment in 1995, the database has grown to include DNA samples from 2.7 million individuals, or 5.2% of the UK's population, many of whom have neither been charged with, or convicted of, any offence.<ref name="ncbihelen">{{cite web|last=Wallace|first=Helen|title=The UK National DNA Database: Balancing crime detection, human rights and privacy|pmc=1490298|publisher=Science and Society}}</ref> *'''[[Tempora]]''': Launched in the autumn of 2011, this initiative allows the [[GCHQ]] to set up a large-scale [[Data buffer|buffer]] that is capable of storing internet content for 3 days and [[metadata]] for 30 days.<ref>{{cite news|title=GCHQ taps fibre-optic cables for secret access to world's communications|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/jun/21/gchq-cables-secret-world-communications-nsa|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|accessdate=21 June 2013|location=London|first1=Ewen|last1=MacAskill|first2=Julian|last2=Borger|first3=Nick|last3=Hopkins|date=21 June 2013}}</ref> *'''[[Royal Concierge]]''': prototyped in 2010, sends daily alerts to [[Government Communications Headquarters|GCHQ]] whenever a booking is made from a ".gov." [[second-level domain]] at select hotels worldwide.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/gchq-monitors-hotel-reservations-to-track-diplomats-a-933914.html|title='Royal Concierge': GCHQ Monitors Hotel Reservations to Track Diplomats|last=Poitras|first=Laura|author2=Marcel Rosenbach |author3=Holger Stark |date=2013-11-17|publisher=Spiegel|accessdate=17 November 2013}}</ref>
=== United States === {{NSA surveillance | 1 }} {{Further information |Mass surveillance in the United States}} [[File:Verizon court order FBI.jpg|thumb|A [[top secret]] document leaked by [[Edward Snowden]] to ''[[The Guardian]]'' in 2013, originally due to be [[Declassification|declassified]] on 12 April 2038.]]
* '''[[Boundless Informant]]''': A system deployed by the [[National Security Agency]] to analyze global electronic information. In March 2013, Boundless Informant gathered 14 billion data reports from [[Iran]], 6.3 billion from [[India]], and 2.8 billion from the [[United States]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Meet 'Boundless Informant,' the NSA's Secret Tool for Tracking Global Surveillance Data|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2013/06/meet-boundless-informant-the-nsas-secret-tool-for-tracking-global-surveillance-data/276686/|publisher=''[[The Atlantic]]''|accessdate=13 June 2013|quote=The country where the largest amount of intelligence was gathered was, unsurprisingly, Iran: Boundless Informant shows more than 14 billion reports in that period. The second-largest collection came from Pakistan, with 13.5 billion reports. Jordan -- which is, yes, one of America's closest Arab allies -- had 12.7 billion reports. Egypt came in fourth (7.6 billion reports), and India in fifth with 6.3 billion. And when it comes to the U.S.? "The Boundless Informant documents show the agency collecting almost 3 billion pieces of intelligence from US computer networks over a 30-day period ending in March 2013."}}</ref> * '''[[Bullrun (code name)|BULLRUN]]''': a highly classified U.S. [[National Security Agency]] program to preserve its ability to eavesdrop on encrypted communications by influencing and weakening encryption standards, by obtaining master encryption keys, and by gaining access to data before or after it is encrypted either by agreement, by force of law, or by computer network exploitation (hacking). * '''[[Carnivore (software)|Carnivore]]''': A system implemented by the Federal Bureau of Investigation that was designed to monitor email and electronic communications. Apparently replaced by commercial software such as [[NarusInsight]]. * '''[[Comprehensive National Cybersecurity Initiative]]''' * '''[[DCSNet]]''': The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI)'s [[point-and-click]] surveillance system that can perform instant wiretaps on any telecommunications device located in the [[United States]].<ref name="wired.com">[https://www.wired.com/politics/security/news/2007/08/wiretap Point, Click ... Eavesdrop: How the FBI Wiretap Net Operates].</ref> * '''[[Fairview (surveillance program)|Fairview]]''': A [[mass surveillance]] program directed at foreign mobile phone users. * '''[[Financial Crimes Enforcement Network]]''': A bureau of the [[United States Department of the Treasury|Department of the Treasury]] that collects and analyzes financial transactions in order to combat [[financial crimes]]. * '''[[ICREACH]]''': Surveillance [[Front and back ends|frontend]] [[Graphical user interface|GUI]] that is shared with 23 government agencies, including the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]], [[Drug Enforcement Administration|DEA]], and [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]], to search illegally collected personal records. * '''[[Magic Lantern (software)|Magic Lantern]]''': A [[keystroke logging]] [[software]] deployed by the FBI in the form of an [[e-mail attachment]]. When activated, it acts as a [[trojan horse]] and allows the FBI to decrypt user communications.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://usgovinfo.about.com/library/weekly/aa121401a.htm |title=FBI Has a Magic Lantern |publisher=Usgovinfo.about.com |accessdate= 23 February 2009}}</ref> * '''[[Main Core]]''': A personal and financial database storing information of millions of U.S. citizens believed to be threats to [[national security]].<ref name="Salon">{{cite web |url=http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2008/07/23/new_churchcomm/# |title=Exposing Bush's historic abuse of power |last=Shorrock |first=Tim |publisher=Salon.com |date=23 July 2008 |accessdate=19 December 2010 |pages= }}</ref> The data mostly comes from the [[National Security Agency|NSA]], [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]], [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]], as well as other government sources.<ref name="Salon"/> * '''[[MAINWAY]]''': NSA database containing [[metadata]] for hundreds of billions of [[telephone call]]s made through the four largest [[telephone company|telephone carriers]] in the United States. * '''[[DHS media monitoring services|Media monitoring services]]''', A proposed DHS database for monitoring all global news sources and media influencers. * '''[[Muscular (surveillance program)|MUSCULAR]]''': Overseas wiretapping of [[Google#Google data centers|Google]]'s and [[Yahoo#Privacy|Yahoo]]'s unencrypted internal networks by the NSA. * '''[[MYSTIC (surveillance program)|MYSTIC]]''' is a voice interception program used by the National Security Agency. * '''[[Nationwide Suspicious Activity Reporting Initiative]]''': Under this government initiative, a [[Suspicious Activity Report (justice and homeland security)|Suspicious Activity Report]] (SAR) may be filed by law enforcers, public safety personnel, owners of critical infrastructure or the general public. * '''[[NSA ANT catalog]]:''' a 50-page document listing technology available to the United States National Security Agency (NSA) ANT division to aid in cyber-surveillance. * '''[[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]]''': A clandestine national security electronic surveillance program operated by the United States National Security Agency (NSA) which can target customers of participating corporations outside or inside the United States. * '''[[Room 641A]]''': A telecommunication interception facility operated by [[AT&T]] for the U.S. National Security Agency. * '''[[Sentry Eagle]]''': efforts to monitor and attack an adversary's cyberspace through capabilities include SIGINT, Computer Network Exploitation (CNE), Information Assurance, Computer Network Defense (CND), Network Warfare, and Computer Network Attack (CNA). The efforts included weakening US commercial encryption systems.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://firstlook.org/theintercept/2014/10/10/core-secrets/ | title=Core Secrets: NSA Saboteurs in China and Germany| work=The Intercept | accessdate=11 October 2014 | author=Maass, Poitras}}</ref> * '''[[Special Collection Service]]''' (SCS): A [[black budget]] program that is responsible for "close surveillance, burglary, wiretapping, breaking and entering." It employs [[covert listening device]] technologies to bug foreign embassies, communications centers, computer facilities, fiber-optic networks, and government installations.<ref name=lichtblau01>{{cite news |last=Lichtblau |first=Eric |authorlink=Eric Lichtblau |title=Spy Suspect May Have Revealed U.S. Bugging; Espionage: Hanssen left signs that he told Russia where top-secret overseas eavesdropping devices are placed, officials say |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=28 February 2001 |page=A1 | url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/updates2/lat_spy010228.htm | archivedate=17 April 2001 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010417230720/http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/updates2/lat_spy010228.htm}}</ref> * '''[[Stellar Wind|Stellar Wind (code name)]]''': The [[open secret]] [[code name]] for four surveillance programs. * '''[[Tailored Access Operations]]''': Intelligence-gathering unit of the NSA that is capable of harvesting approximately 2 [[petabyte]]s of data per hour.<ref name=Riley>{{cite web|last=Riley|first=Michael|title=How the U.S. Government Hacks the World|url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2013-05-23/how-the-u-dot-s-dot-government-hacks-the-world|work =[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]|accessdate=23 May 2013|date=23 May 2013}}</ref><ref name="Aid2010">{{cite book|last=Aid|first=Matthew M.|title=The Secret Sentry: The Untold History of the National Security Agency|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x_K2rb-OShMC&pg=PA311|accessdate=22 May 2013|date=8 June 2010|publisher=Bloomsbury USA|isbn=978-1-60819-096-6|page=311}}</ref> * '''[[Terrorist Finance Tracking Program]]''': A joint initiative run by the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] and the [[United States Department of the Treasury|Department of the Treasury]] to access the SWIFT ([[Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication]]) transaction database as part of the [[George W. Bush administration|Bush administration]]'s "Global [[War on Terrorism]]". According to the U.S. government, its efforts to [[counter-terrorism|counter terrorist activities]] were compromised after the existence of the Terrorist Finance Tracking Program was leaked to the media.<ref>Blustein, Paul, Gellman, Barton, and Linzer, Dafna. "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/06/23/AR2006062300167.html Bank Records Secretly Tapped]", ''Washington Post'', 23 June 2006. Accessed 23 June 2006.</ref> * '''[[Turbulence]]''' (NSA): Turbulence is a United States National Security Agency (NSA) information-technology project started circa 2005. It was developed in small, inexpensive "test" pieces rather than one grand plan like its failed predecessor, the Trailblazer Project. It also includes offensive cyberwarfare capabilities, like injecting malware into remote computers. The U.S. Congress criticized the project in 2007 for having similar bureaucratic problems as the Trailblazer Project.<ref>Thomas Drake on The Real News "[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ygCduZKJF0o]", ''The Real News'', 3 August 2015. Accessed 19 August 2015.</ref> * '''[[United States Intelligence Community|US Intelligence Community]]''' (IC): A cooperative federation of 16 government agencies working together, but also separately, to gather intelligence and conduct [[espionage]]. * '''[[Utah Data Center]]''': The Intelligence Community's US$1.5 billion [[Computer data storage|data storage]] center that is designed to store extremely large amounts of data, on the scale of [[yottabytes]].<ref name="cnet">{{cite news| author = Trenholm, Rich | url=http://crave.cnet.co.uk/gadgets/nsa-to-store-yottabytes-in-utah-data-centre-49304118/|title=NSA to Store Yottabytes in Utah Data Centre | publisher =[[CNET]]|accessdate= 13 June 2013}}</ref><ref name="bamford1">{{cite news | title = The NSA Is Building the Country’s Biggest Spy Center (Watch What You Say) | first = James | last = Bamford | authorlink = James Bamford | url = https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2012/03/ff_nsadatacenter/all/1 | work = [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] | date = 15 March 2012 | accessdate = 5 April 2012 }}</ref><ref name="Kenyon">{{cite news |url=http://defensesystems.com/Articles/2011/01/07/NSA-spy-cyber-intelligence-data-center-Utah.aspx|title=New NSA data center breaks ground on construction -- Defense Systems|last=Kenyon|first=Henry|date= 7 January 2011|publisher=Defense Systems|accessdate=11 August 2011}}</ref> * '''[[X-Keyscore]]''': A system used by the United States National Security Agency for searching and analysing internet data about foreign nationals.
== Unclear origin == * '''[[GhostNet]]''': A fictitious code name given to a large-scale surveillance project that is believed to be operated by the [[People's Republic of China]].<ref name="NY-TIMES">{{cite news| title=Vast Spy System Loots Computers in 103 Countries | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/29/technology/29spy.html | work = [[The New York Times]] | date=28 March 2009 | accessdate=29 March 2009 | author = [[John Markoff|Markoff, John]]}}</ref> * '''[[Stuxnet]]''': It is the first discovered [[malware]] that spies on industrial systems, and it was used to attack [[Iran]]'s nuclear facilities.<ref name=compworld>{{cite web |url = http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/print/9185419/Siemens_Stuxnet_worm_hit_industrial_systems?taxonomyName=Network+Security&taxonomyId=142 |author = Robert McMillan |date = 16 September 2010 |publisher = Computerworld |accessdate = 16 September 2010 |title = Siemens: Stuxnet worm hit industrial systems |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20120525053210/http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/print/9185419/Siemens_Stuxnet_worm_hit_industrial_systems?taxonomyName=Network+Security&taxonomyId=142 |archivedate = 25 May 2012 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> It is believed to have originated from the [[United States]] under the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush administration]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Stuxnet was work of U.S. and Israeli experts, officials say|url=https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2012-06-01/world/35459494_1_nuclear-program-stuxnet-senior-iranian-officials|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|accessdate=11 June 2013|quote=The officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity to describe the classified effort code-named Olympic Games, said it was first developed during the George W. Bush administration and was geared toward damaging Iran’s nuclear capability gradually while sowing confusion among Iranian scientists about the cause of mishaps at a nuclear plant.|first1=Ellen|last1=Nakashima|first2=Joby|last2=Warrick|date=3 June 2012}}</ref>
== Recently discontinued == * ''[[Information Awareness Office]]'': An office established to bring together several DARPA projects focused on applying surveillance and information technology to track and monitor terrorists and other threats to U.S. national security. * '''[[Multistate Anti-Terrorism Information Exchange]]''' (MATRIX): A [[data mining system]] originally developed for the [[Florida Department of Law Enforcement]]. * '''[[Terrorist Surveillance Program]]''': Replaced by [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]]. * '''[[ThinThread]]''': A U.S. National Security Agency (NSA) program that involved wiretapping and sophisticated analysis of the resulting data. * '''[[Trailblazer Project]]''': U.S. National Security Agency (NSA) program intended to develop a capability to analyze data carried on communications networks including cell phone networks and the Internet.

'''Louise Leonard McLaren''' (August 10, 1865 – December 16, 1968) born in [[Wellsboro, Pennsylvania]], was founder of the [[Southern Summer School for Women Workers]].<ref name=DICT>{{cite book|last1=Sicherman|first1=Barbara|last2=Green|first2=Carol Hurd|title=Notable American women : the modern period ; a biographical dictionary|date=1993|publisher=Belknap Press of Harvard Univ. Press|location=Cambridge, Mass [u.a.]|isbn=9780674627338|edition=6th pring.|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=CfGHM9KU7aEC&lpg=PA453&ots=Os_Kpap7ks&dq=%22louise%20leonard%20mclaren%22%20colombia&pg=PA453#v=onepage&q=%22louise%20leonard%20mclaren%22%20colombia&f=false|accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref>
==Early career== She attended [[Finishing school|Miss Beret's School for Ladies]] in [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania]] and went on to earn her A.B. at [[Vassar College]] in 1907; She then taught history until 1914 when she became the YWCA industrial secretary in Wilkes Barre, Pennsylvania. In this capacity she traveled through the south in order to organize women workers in industry. After earning an A.M. in economics at [[Columbia University]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://plexuss.com/college/columbia-university-in-the-city-of-new-york|title=Columbia University New York - Academic Recruiting Network - Plexuss|work=plexuss.com}}</ref> in 1927<ref name=DICT /> she decided to organize the Southern Summer School for Women Workers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://larson.library.emory.edu/marbl/DigProjects/swh/subjects/The%20Southern%20Summer%20School%20for%20Women%20Workers%20in%20Industry.htm|title=The Southern Summer School for Women Workers in Industry|work=emory.edu}}</ref> Leonard recruited a faculty from women's colleges. It was modeled on the [[Bryn Mawr Summer School for Women Workers in Industry]] originated by [[Hilda Worthington Smith]]. She viewed workers' education as a means for social change.<ref>Klotter, James C. ''The Human Tradition in the Old South.'' Wilmington, Del: SR Books, 2003.</ref> Writing in ''Vassar Quarterly'' about her work she commented, "these awakening workers of the South have a chance to get worker's education,<ref>[[The Story of Philosophy]]</ref> as they demand social and economic enfranchisement."<ref>{{cite web|first=Louise |last=McLaren|title=Workers Education in the South|publisher=''Vassar Quarterly''|year=1935|url=http://larson.library.emory.edu/marbl/DigProjects/swh/images/Barker%20528/0528-029.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref>
==To the South==
The first Southern Summer School met at rented facilities in 1927 at [[Sweet Briar College]] in Virginia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://larson.library.emory.edu/marbl/DigProjects/swh/images/Barker%20528/0528-026.htm|title=0528-026|work=emory.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://larson.library.emory.edu/marbl/DigProjects/swh/images/Barker%20528/0528-041.pdf|format=PDF|title=Southern Students tell their stories |website=larson.library.emory.edu}}</ref> It never had permanent quarters, and moved each year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://larson.library.emory.edu/marbl/DigProjects/swh/images/Barker%20528/0528-088.pdf|format=PDF|title=Photos of the class 1929 |website=larson.library.emory.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://larson.library.emory.edu/marbl/DigProjects/swh/images/Barker%20528/0528-051.pdf|format=PDF|title=Burnsville, NC|website=larson.library.emory.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://larson.library.emory.edu/marbl/DigProjects/swh/images/Barker%20528/0528-053.pdf|format=PDF|title=Arden, NC|website=larson.library.emory.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://larson.library.emory.edu/marbl/DigProjects/swh/images/Barker%20528/0528-048.pdf|format=PDF|title=Ashville, NC|website=larson.library.emory.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://larson.library.emory.edu/marbl/DigProjects/swh/images/Barker%20528/0528-003.pdf|format=PDF|title=Brochure listing Policy makers and Advisors |website=larson.library.emory.edu}}</ref> The 25 students each year were carefully chosen and all white,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://larson.library.emory.edu/marbl/DigProjects/swh/images/Barker%20528/0528-081.pdf|format=PDF|title=1939 student list |website=larson.library.emory.edu}}</ref> but the philosophy that Louise espoused made no difference between faculty and student, emphasizing ''"there is no line drawn between faculty and student as there is in academic life."'' The students were chosen to represent all the typical industries of the south<ref>{{cite web|url=http://larson.library.emory.edu/marbl/DigProjects/swh/images/Barker%20528/0528-015.pdf|format=PDF|title=Louise Lerner writings from Barker archives |website=larson.library.emory.edu}}</ref> and Leonard was intent on teaching the "social attitudes appropriate to the machine age".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://spectatorarchive.library.columbia.edu/cgi-bin/columbia?a=d&d=cs19360320-01.2.4|title=Columbia Daily Spectator 20 March 1936 — Columbia Spectator|work=columbia.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://larson.library.emory.edu/marbl/DigProjects/swh/images/Barker%20528/0528-007.pdf|format=PDF|title=Phamplet Southern Women Workers |website=larson.library.emory.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://larson.library.emory.edu/marbl/DigProjects/swh/images/Barker%20528/0528-037.pdf|format=PDF|title=Phamplet Southern School |website=larson.library.emory.edu}}</ref> In 1930 Louise Leonard married Myron Mclaren, a professor at St.Johns college in Maryland. When he lost his job during the depression she supported them both. The couple was childless and she devoted herself to the work, under her charge more than 300 working class women came to summer residence, being trained as leaders in their fields.<ref>{{cite book|title=Notable American Women: The Modern Period : a Biographical Dictionary|first=Barbara|last=Sicherman|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CfGHM9KU7aEC&pg=PA453&lpg=PA453&dq=Louise+Leonard+McLaren&source=bl&ots=Os_Nrev4ir&sig=mxyDr0quLdFx9zryXKKDJogiKuQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=hwI5Vfe8KoLIsQTqwoHICA&ved=0CDoQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=Louise%20Leonard%20McLaren&f=false}}</ref> In 1938 men were included in the residence program and by 1940 half of the students were men.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PBj5-zHEMvoC&pg=PA222&lpg=PA222&dq=Louise+Leonard+McLaren&source=bl&ots=4-P4GYo9wj&sig=QmYjrAb6gBCtvXpv-U-9gNfBKUQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=hwI5Vfe8KoLIsQTqwoHICA&ved=0CDUQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=Louise%20Leonard%20McLaren&f=false|title=Biographical Dictionary of Modern American Educators|work=google.com}}</ref> She had the support of the labor unions and had a commitment to the tenets of workers' education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://larson.library.emory.edu/marbl/DigProjects/swh/images/Barker%20528/0528-018.pdf|format=PDF|title=Phamplet on Summer school|website=larson.library.emory.edu}}</ref>
==Later career==
In 1944 Louise McLaren moved to [[New York City]] where she served as organizer for the [[Congress of Industrial Organizations]] Political Action committee. She held various positions eventually retiring from a teaching and research position with the American Labor Education Service. She was part of a network of reform-minded women that met in the 1920s and later became academic social scientists (including Marie Algor, [[Hilda Worthington Smith|Hilda (Jane) Smith]], Mary C. Barker, Ernestine Friedmann, Alice Shoemaker, Amy Bruce, and Eleanor G. Coit). Some were former YWCA industrial and executive secretaries whom went on to establish summer schools, taught workers' education programs, did research and field work, and also held seminars and conferences for workers' education. Throughout the years of cooperative work in the field they managed to stay in touch and this resulted in lasting friendships.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~sch00224|title=Coit, Eleanor G. Papers, 1894-1971: A Finding Aid|work=harvard.edu}}</ref>
She died in East Stroudsburg, Pa. in 1968 of heart disease at age 83. She had a vision of industrial society and with an unfailing sense of optimism and with hard work and dedication inspired several generations of southern working women.
==Further reading== *"Recognizing Regional Differences: The Southern Summer School for Women Workers," in ''Sisterhood and Solidarity: Workers' Education for Women'', 1914-1984, edited by Joyce Kornbluh and Mary Frederickson, Philadelphia: Temple University Press, 1984, 148-186. *"Biographical sketches of Mary C. Barker and Louise Leonard McLaren" in ''Notable American Women, The Modern Period'', edited by Barbara Sicherman and Carol Hurd Green (Cambridge:Harvard University Press, 1980) pp. 50-52, 452-254. *"The Southern Summer School for Women Workers in Industry," Southern Exposure, in ''Generations: Women in the South'', Vol. 2 (1977) *Oral history<ref>{{cite web|url=http://docsouth.unc.edu/sohp/G-0020/excerpts/excerpt_8564.html|title=Documenting the American South: Oral Histories of the American South|work=unc.edu}}</ref> *''Notable American Women: The Modern Period : a Biographical Dictionary'' by Barbara Sicherman pg. 453 *''Biographical Dictionary of Modern American Educators'' by Frederik Ohles, Shirley M. Ohles, John G. Ramsay pg.222 * Researcher - Mary E. Frederickson - Emory University<ref>http://ila.emory.edu/home/documents/cv/Frederickson_CV.pdf</ref> * Online Archive<ref>{{cite web|url=http://larson.library.emory.edu/marbl/DigProjects/swh/subjects/browse%20southern%20summer%20school%20materials.htm|title=Browse Southern Summer School for Women Workers in Industry materials|work=emory.edu}}</ref>
